summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have resumed their conflict following Townsend's substitution in the 83rd minute of Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson criticized Townsend for suggesting that if Townsend was included in the England squad, it would open the door for others. However, Merson admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored an equalizer for England against Italy. Despite this, Merson continued to criticize Townsend on social media, leading to a response from Townsend. Although tensions appeared to have eased, Merson once again criticized Townsend after the draw with Burnley.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. If Muto completes a move to Chelsea this summer, he will join their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. The offer is not connected to the £200million sponsorship deal Chelsea signed with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, has earned 11 caps for Japan and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances. He would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves. A £4million deal has been mooted, but Muto has not yet decided to join the club. Muto has scored 13 times in his debut season with FC Tokyo and was named in the J-League's best XI. Yokohama Rubber will become Chelsea's official shirt sponsor from the start of the 2015-16 season.

A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by affecting the gut bacteria that normally help digest food, potentially leading to weight gain. The study, conducted by Finnish researchers, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-old children with records on antibiotic prescriptions. By two years old, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese. Children who had taken antibiotics as babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with repeated prescriptions before the age of two increasing the odds of being overweight. The study did not prove causation but highlighted the potential role of antibiotics in childhood obesity. The lead author warned about the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy. The study also noted that the obesity epidemic is more pronounced in boys, and there is growing concern about the over-prescription of antibiotics leading to antibiotic resistance.

The passage describes an embarrassing incident where a Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, which was captured on camera by a tourist. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing, knocked his bearskin on the side of the box, and dropped his rifle. He quickly scrambled to his feet, but realized the crowd had seen his slip. The incident occurred during a tourist's recording of the event, and the guard is thought to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a regular event at Buckingham Palace, with two detachments under the command of the Captain of The Queen's Guard, who are fully operational soldiers. The Ministry of Defence did not comment on the incident.

The passage discusses the remake of the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally had a massive audience of over 100 million viewers. The remake, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast across A&E, Lifetime, and History networks. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake is described as "original" and "contemporary," drawing from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." Producers will consult scholars in African and African-American history for authenticity. The new adaptation aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation of viewers, including those who may not be familiar with the story. The remake is being produced by Mark Wolper, son of the original's producer, and is expected to resonate with contemporary audiences in the context of racial issues in the United States.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claimed that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. He was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day. The incident left him in tears and he left the job the same day. Lawler, now 64, decided to contact palace officials again after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 1980s. His complaints were ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was interviewed but denied involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will work 'exhaustively and co-operatively' with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the 1990s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping as they drive in a car. The clip includes lines about their life in Oregon, their home, and their anticipation of parenthood. The video was created to share the news with loved ones living far away. The couple mentioned that it was unexpected for the video to gain such widespread attention. The video was filmed over five takes, and after finding out the gender of the child, another video may be made. The couple also shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the clip. The video was inspired by the original theme song from the sitcom, which was originally performed by Will Smith.

The dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt, which featured a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, including costumes, props, and artifacts. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray due to age. It was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who began collecting Hollywood memorabilia in the 1960s. The dress was purchased for $20 by Tumblin after he spotted it on the floor of the Western Costume Company. The auction also featured other top-selling items, including a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500 and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. *Gone With the Wind*, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary and features Hattie McDaniel as the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo officials confirmed that the cheetahs did not attack the child. The incident led to plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the fall.

A speed camera that was previously monitoring the residential road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been re-pointed to focus on a house, despite not functioning for over two years. The camera was part of a batch of 300 fixed speed cameras that were decommissioned in the West Midlands in 2013 due to outdated technology. Instead, mobile camera units and traffic officers are now used for enforcement. A Birmingham City Council spokesman confirmed they are aware of the issue and will have an engineer visit the site. There are no plans to include the camera in a new pilot program using digital technology. The house owners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team. He will participate on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his excitement about being part of the team and mentioned his readiness to run. He also highlighted Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to making his country proud. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico basketball match against Real Madrid, where Barcelona won 85-80. Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division by a small points difference. Neymar also helped Brazil win 1-0 against Chile. Barcelona is competing for a treble of trophies in La Liga, with Neymar and his team set to face Celta Vigo.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, with 20 boats in distress reported on Monday alone. A spokesman for Save the Children reported that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea near the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident and has not found evidence of a capsized boat. There has been an increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with more rescues performed by the Italian Coast Guard. According to the International Organization for Migration, Italy registered over 10,000 migrants in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea during the first weekend of April. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels. Sometimes, captains and crews abandon ships, leaving passengers to fend for themselves.

Arsene Wenger, the manager of Arsenal, is glad that Alexis Sanchez has chosen to join Arsenal over Liverpool. Sanchez was convinced to continue his career under Wenger's guidance after being offered a place at Arsenal following his release by Barcelona. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage during negotiations involving Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Sanchez has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to his new environment demonstrates his exceptional qualities. He also plays down speculation about a potential transfer for Raheem Sterling, praising Liverpool's performance under Brendan Rodgers.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He aims to set a new mark, with the current record held by Australian Rohan Dennis at 52.491km. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix, is expected to set a record that will last for some time. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets available from April 19. Wiggins is also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams, the twice French Open champion, faced a tough match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, which served as a 'eye-opener' for her as the claycourt season began. Despite winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams was not impressed with her performance, acknowledging she was not fully prepared for clay courts. The US team was defeated 3-2, leading to their relegation to World Group II. Williams' doubles loss against Errani and Flavia Pennetta impacted her flawless Fed Cup record. The US team's captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasized the need to work harder to regain their position in the World Group next year.

River Plate are interested in signing Radamel Falcao, a former player who spent eight years with the club before joining Porto in 2009. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed a desire to bring Falcao back, stating that the doors are open. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, but has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three times in two games. Falcao, who joined River Plate at 15 in 2001, scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for the club during his four seasons.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a blurred city background, showcasing her long flowing locks. The partnership was facilitated by MILES agency, and the campaign launched with a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson uses Batiste regularly, and her manager, Mark Hargreaves, noted the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who shot Aaron Siler, was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after Siler was killed in March. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was described as "disrespectful" by Siler's family and friends, who felt it was a tribute to Torres for killing Siler. The association claimed the billboard was to thank the community for its support. Siler was shot after being confronted by Torres, who is on leave pending an investigation. The shooting followed a vehicle and foot pursuit, and occurred 10 days after Torres shot Terry Knight, who was armed with knives. The investigation into Knight's shooting was deemed justified, while the investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Iranian border guards have clashed with militants near the border with Pakistan, resulting in eight Iranian deaths and three militants killed. The militants, associated with the group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to arrest the remaining militants. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group based in Balochistan, has previously attacked Iranian territory and aims to reduce Iranian influence in Pakistan. The Pakistani government condemned the attack as terrorism and is investigating the incident, requesting evidence from Iran.

The passage discusses how the classic video game "Space Invaders" has inspired a political discussion in Japan regarding the possibility of extraterrestrial life. Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an unidentified flying object (UFO) from outer space. Former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, known for his political and entertainment endeavors, asked about the ASDF's encounters with UFOs, prompting Nakatani's response. Inoki also claimed to have seen a UFO but was unsure if aliens existed. This exchange is part of a broader historical context, as Japanese politicians have previously discussed the legal implications of extraterrestrial invasions under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed while he was standing on its rim. He had been concerned about the cleanliness of the seat and avoided sitting. The toilet, which was not designed for standing, tipped over, causing injuries. Jin initially told his friends he was squatting but later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities stated the incident was an accident and reminded passengers that the toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced back to him. Rebbie is accused of sexually abusing the girl and others over a four-year period, filming them in a bathroom with a hidden camera. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl discovered the camera in March, revealing that Rebbie had been watching her for years, including when she was undressing and believed to be asleep. Investigators found 41 videos, 34 of which showed victims showering, with some containing close-up images of children's genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family is unknown.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series of father-daughter portraits captures teenagers smiling while their fathers leap into the air, showcasing the fathers' fun side. The series, part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," features fathers in sharp suits leaping dramatically next to their daughters, often with pained expressions. The photos, taken in front of Japanese landmarks, highlight the contrast between the daughters' casual clothing and their fathers' formal attire. The series has generated significant online interest for its unique and curious approach to father-daughter portraits.

Kevin Pietersen has rejoined Surrey ahead of the County Championship season, with the hope of making a comeback in the England Test team. His potential return to the international set-up follows the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director, which has paved the way for Pietersen's reintegration. Pietersen last played international cricket during the 2014 Ashes tour, which ended in a disastrous whitewash defeat. He is now focusing on the new county championship season, with Surrey set to begin their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19. Pietersen was photographed at the KIA Oval, where he appeared in a jovial mood and engaged with photographers, showing a mix of thoughtfulness and enthusiasm as he looks ahead to his potential return to the England team.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have sacked coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. After being reinstated by owner Angelo Massone following a poor performance, Ze Maria angered Massone again after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, leading to his dismissal. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender and Inter Milan player, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao is regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao joined United on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to match his previous performance, partly due to a serious knee injury. Despite scoring only four goals, United are unlikely to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he was not feeling well, and believes he would have had the opportunity to participate in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy in Saturday. The robber, described as very tall, was wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. He demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter, took the till and approximately $1,500 in cash, and fled the scene. The police have not found any weapons and are asking the public for information to help identify the suspect. Anyone with information can contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested again after being accused of having sex with two 15-year-old students on consecutive nights in January. She was initially arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with one student and was released on bail. Granado admitted to kissing and allowing a 15-year-old student to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Following new accusations from a second student, Granado was arrested again on Monday and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district confirmed they took immediate action, placing her on administrative leave to prevent her from working with students.

A video of a large crocodile holding a dead dog in its jaws while swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, has been viewed over 500,000 times. The incident occurred during a holiday for New Zealander Tim Weston and his wife, who witnessed the crocodile holding the dog for an extended period. The dog belonged to the owner of a local bike shop. The crocodile was reportedly in a sanctuary 200 meters away from the marina. Social media users reacted with horror to the video, with some expressing fear of crocodiles. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, which is located among mangroves where they have lived for centuries. Due to urbanization, crocodiles are now more frequently encountered by humans.

Steve Bruce is confident Hull City can avoid relegation in the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton. With six wins in the season, Bruce believes nine or eight wins might be enough. Hull now have six crucial games left, including tough matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. The team's struggles are attributed to long-term injuries to key players, but Bruce remains optimistic. Southampton moved to fifth in the table after the match, while Koeman addressed a team issue involving Sadio Mane and a penalty decision.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to alter their exam answers, which invalidated his school's SATs results. The changes were made despite the exam session having concluded. Guffick also altered some of the pupils' answers himself before the papers were submitted. An investigation by the local education authority found that some pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions, and Guffick had done the same. As a result, the Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the school. Guffick was forced to resign and admitted the allegations. Although he claimed the changes were to make the answers more legible, the panel found his actions to be dishonest and unacceptable. The Education Secretary, Nicky Morgan, banned Guffick from the classroom, stating his actions had a serious impact on the school's results. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, has been married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri since last year, following a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius. The couple, who have been dating since 2012, have a son together. Despite struggling for playing time at Manchester United, where he has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons, Lindegaard has enjoyed a positive personal life, including a public display of affection with his wife on social media. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is a model with a significant following on Instagram. Lindegaard has also been linked with a move to FC Midtjylland but no agreement was reached on a transfer fee.

The glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, which have been a landmark in the Bronx since 1976, failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction. The 13 letters, expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, only fetched $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the letters in 2008 for an undisclosed amount and wanted a new generation to own and enjoy them. The letters were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008 after the stadium's final game. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s was auctioned for $112,500, exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Brendan Rodgers, Liverpool's manager, reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordan Ibe of their professional responsibilities and urged them to learn from a recent incident. Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide and was later pictured with Ibe using shisha pipes. Although Rodgers spoke to both players, he has decided not to discipline them and wants to move on from the matter. Rodgers emphasized the importance of professionalism and the responsibilities of elite sportspeople. He also mentioned his focus on preparing Liverpool for their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, despite previous setbacks in the title race and Capital One Cup. Rodgers believes that losing is part of the journey and that the team is ready to progress. He has not yet decided whether to recall Steven Gerrard for the semi-final.

Mesut Ozil, the Arsenal playmaker, returned to London after the international break and posted a picture of himself relaxing with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." He played a key role in Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who joined Arsenal for £42.5million in 2013, is expected to start in the Premier League match against Liverpool. He has been in good form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. Ozil has adjusted well to English football, stating he fits in 'perfectly' due to the demanding schedule and preference for playing multiple matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace Luis Enrique and are 'very happy' with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer, is six games away from winning the title and has impressed during his tenure. Bartomeu emphasized that there is time to discuss Enrique's contract in the future and that Enrique is focused on La Liga and the team. After a Champions League game against PSG, Bartomeu noted Enrique's dedication to preparing for the next match. Enrique's team comfortably defeated Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay until the summer of 2020. The deal is worth around £100,000-a-week and comes after 14 months remaining on his current contract. Henderson, 24, is the third major player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to agree to a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He has been one of the most improved players under Rodgers' management, contributing 13 assists and seven goals from midfield. Henderson is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as Liverpool's captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis has stated his intention to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him in the summer. Luis, who joined Chelsea from Atletico in July, has struggled to adapt to the left back position at the club. However, he has been focused on his role with Chelsea, participating in Brazil's friendly matches and emphasizing the importance of winning every game in the Premier League title race. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has also encouraged the team to stay focused and continue their pursuit of the league title.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. The incident occurred during a try by Hughes for Northampton on March 27, where Hughes' knee collided with North's head, leaving North unconscious and requiring medical attention. Although there was no intent, Hughes received a ban initially. Following an appeal and public outcry, the ban was rescinded. Hughes is now free to return to play but is not in the match-day squad for Wasps' upcoming game. The appeal panel concluded the incident was accidental, with no foul play involved.

A fiery sunset was observed in Washington, with the reddish color catching the attention of Seattle native Tim Durkan, who shared photos of the phenomenon on CNN iReport. The sunsets were caused by wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which started with farmers burning grass but quickly spread due to strong winds. The fires destroyed many villages, though rescue crews managed to control them. Smoke from the fires was carried by winds across the Pacific Ocean, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red and orange hues of the sunsets are due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange to pass through. As the smoke dissipates, the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. After the car was found by Mick Sexton, who recognized it and returned it to her, she was surprised to find it with new red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Rather than being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is now cleaning the car to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Sexton. The smoothie, called "Sexton on Wheels," includes banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream.

Manchester City players could lose £500,000 in bonuses per player if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club has incentivized contracts with star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to ensure compliance with financial fair play rules. Manchester City lost to Manchester United in the 169th derby, leaving their European qualification hopes in doubt. The team is currently in fourth place and is four points behind Liverpool. The top three teams automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The City squad has around £12 million at stake. The manager, Manuel Pellegrini, admitted the team has struggled, losing seven games and failing in the FA Cup and Champions League. They are now competing to sign top players like Paul Pogba, while Manchester United, now four points clear, is confident of adding top talent in the next transfer window.

In a 'mini-derby' between Manchester United and Altrincham, United won 1-0 with a goal from Callum Gribbin, an English Under 18 player. The match, played at Altrincham's Moss Lane, featured 13 English players, with 10 being Mancunian. The game was well-attended with free entry and a crowd of over 1,000. The match was part of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League, and the result left United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand. Altrincham, who had previously lost both matches in the play-off series, faced a tough challenge. The game highlighted the potential of young talents on both sides, with Gribbin's performance drawing attention. Despite a few near-misses, United's victory was a positive outcome for the club.

Joe Hart, an England ace and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th international cap in the same match, expressed admiration for Buffon's inspiration and continued learning from him. Hart also expressed his pride in achieving his 50th cap and his determination to keep playing well for his club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant, has partnered with the Postmates app to offer food delivery services in 67 cities, tapping into the $70 billion food delivery market. The partnership includes a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Chipotle has previously declined other delivery service collaborations but has now agreed with Postmates. The restaurant has seen growth, with two presidential candidates, Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, visiting their locations. Additionally, other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or have already launched delivery programs.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from consideration for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted of the 2013 bombings. They emphasize the emotional toll on their family, including the loss of their 8-year-old son, Martin, and the severe injuries to their daughter, Jane. The Richards argue that the death penalty could lead to prolonged appeals and retraumatization, and they support a life sentence without the possibility of release. They stress that their plea is personal and not a general stance against the death penalty.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing £400 million. The plane, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, has been modified to accommodate a single owner and dozens of guests. It features multiple lounges, a dining room with a kitchen, a conference room, an onboard restaurant, and a master bedroom with a large bed and relaxation areas. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with a focus on comfort and exclusivity, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with the Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station, successfully delivering supplies and research equipment. The mission was the second attempt, as the first was canceled due to weather. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a floating barge but tipped over and failed. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to reduce space travel costs, a goal it has been pursuing since its first attempt in January. The Dragon will dock with the space station, deliver supplies, and later return to Earth after being filled with experiments and trash. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station, making it the first private company to dock with the station.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel, located at the Westgate Hotel, is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. A contest was launched with NBC's Today show to find an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding' on April 23. The winning couple will be married at the chapel, receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla emphasized that the wedding chapel is a serious, high-quality event, not a joke, and no impersonators will be allowed.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a strong performance in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, tying the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Liverpool has been struggling after poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal but is now in a position to close the four-point gap on Manchester City. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal, helping secure the win. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal, but it was not awarded. The win is a crucial step for Liverpool as they aim to challenge for the Champions League spot.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a key Serie A match for Champions League positions. Miralem Pjanic scored the opening goal in the 25th minute with a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio. Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches, remaining fifth in the league. The match was held under strict security measures due to the death of a fan from a previous incident. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic quickly made an impact. Napoli had a potential penalty but no protest, and de Sanctis was outstanding in the second half. Insigne made his debut for Napoli after a knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspired season in League One, remaining in mid-table mediocrity. Their draw against Fleetwood Town, which ended 0-0, was uneventful and tested the patience of fans. The media team created a 27-second highlight reel of the match, featuring only the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle, as there was no goal to showcase. The match highlights were deemed a "must-see" video for football fans.

The passage describes a unique relationship between a man named Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid. Giroux, who uploads fish videos to his YouTube channel, has developed a bond with the fish through daily interaction, including gentle stroking and massaging. The fish, initially shy, becomes more sociable after Giroux removed bullying tank mates and began feeding it by hand. The fish shows affection by staying still, swimming in circles, and even swimming up Giroux's arm. Giroux notes that the fish becomes frustrated if not interacted with daily and is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

Ben Stokes is known for his fiery and aggressive personality within the England cricket team. Despite his reputation, he must channel his aggression in a controlled manner to ensure it contributes to the team's success. Stokes has a history of clashes, such as punching a locker after being dismissed, but has shown improvement after talking to England's coach, Peter Moores. Stokes is valued for his exuberance and desire to take on opponents, which can bring runs and wickets. However, the team must balance his natural aggression with careful management to avoid being pigeonholed. England aims to have Stokes play as much as possible this summer, along with Adil Rashid, to help both players grow into the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium has been declared a 33,000 sell-out. The match, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, is a key game in Group B, where Wales and Belgium are tied on 11 points. Wales is in a strong position to qualify for the 2016 World Cup, having risen to the top of the group on goal difference. A 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted expectations for Wales to secure one of the two automatic qualification spots. The FAW reported high demand for tickets, and the match is being held at Cardiff City Stadium due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the date. The Wales squad prefers playing at Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium.

The England Under-17 squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria has been named by coach John Peacock. The team, known as the Young Lions, are the defending champions having defeated Holland in the final last year. They have a 100% qualifying record and will compete in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. The squad includes young talents from Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, and Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi of Arsenal. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. The Young Lions will play against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing Anderlecht's 14-year-old playmaker, Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from their youth academy. Patoulidis has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona but rejected an offer to join Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. City have discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, in hopes of securing a deal. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to strengthen the team's future by acquiring Patoulidis.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. She worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death and has been bailed, with further questioning scheduled. Police are appealing for information from anyone who may have had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and is urging people to come forward to learn more about the circumstances of her death.

Dawn, a woman who has experienced seven miscarriages, was devastated when her family friend, Jamie, stole £207 she had saved for a grave stone for her unborn child. After a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle show confirmed Jamie's guilt, Dawn broke down in tears and left the show. The money was meant to cover a £500 grave stone for her child, and she felt betrayed after being lied to by Jamie, who also blamed his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her emotional distress, highlighting the impact of the theft on her grief and sense of trust.

The passage discusses the release of over 200 Yazidis by ISIS, a minority group that was targeted and displaced when ISIS took over their towns in northern Iraq last summer. Most of those released were women and children, with the rest being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders, though the exact reason was not specified. The freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga force and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. This follows previous releases of Yazidis by ISIS, which have included children and the elderly. The Yazidis, of Kurdish descent, are a pre-Islamic religious group that has faced persecution, with ISIS showing extraordinary cruelty towards them. The attack on Sinjar led to a major humanitarian crisis, with many Yazidis fleeing into the mountains and others into Syria. The international community, including the U.S., responded with airstrikes against ISIS. Approximately 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, making up less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane is being recognized for his outstanding performance this season, as he is nominated for both the PFA Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year awards. To celebrate his achievements, a new animation has been created by Copa90, featuring some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season. The animation includes his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', is released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane is up against competitors such as Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right manager for Liverpool despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, emphasized that Rodgers' future should not be determined by a single season. He acknowledged the challenges of integrating new players and the need for correct signings to improve the team. Carragher also highlighted his own commitment to giving back to his community through his 23 Foundation, reflecting on his upbringing in Bootle and the importance of support in achieving success.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it was detected on an X-ray machine. The toy, a plastic Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk, leading to a frisk and the child being forced to hand it over. The boy's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security staff for being 'over-zealous' and for the inconvenience caused. The family was delayed and missed their flight to Lanzarote. After returning from their holiday, James was given a new toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized and offered to post the toy back, but the airport defended the decision, stating that safety and security are their top priorities and that items resembling prohibited items cannot be allowed through security.

Rich, a 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife with specific requirements, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, and skilled in various areas such as cooking and outdoor activities. The advertisement detailed his personal attributes, such as being athletic, tattooed, and a lover of the outdoors. He offered various benefits to the successful candidate, including a gym membership, a car, and a phone, and stated he is not shy of spending money on his partner. The ad also mentioned that former partners should not apply, and the Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact the man behind the advertisement.

The passage discusses football association chairman Greg Dyke's efforts to implement changes in English football, supported by five former England managers. Dyke aims to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and adjust the definition of 'home-grown' players to require training in England for three years before the age of 18. These proposals face opposition from the Premier League. The former England managers argue that blocking the proposals could harm the English game and hinder England's chances of winning the World Cup. They also highlight the current lack of opportunity for young talent, despite the emergence of promising players like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling.

Demelza Poldark is now the proud mother to Ross Poldark's latest addition, with the baby's birth occurring within minutes of the previous episode's climax. Fans have expressed their longing for Ross, but he remains single. The timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is questionable, as she is shown to be eight months pregnant and gives birth within minutes, with the last month of her pregnancy passing in a short time. This is similar to a previous pregnancy on the show that saw a character go to full term between episodes.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused and not be distracted by relegation rivals. After two consecutive wins, including a 3-2 victory against West Brom that secured a survival lifeline, Leicester is currently three points from safety in the Barclays Premier League but remains bottom of the table. Jamie Vardy's injury-time goal against West Brom improved their chances of survival. Pearson emphasized the importance of concentrating on their own performance and not getting caught up in the competition with other teams. He believes that staying focused on their own games will give them a realistic chance of avoiding relegation.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record set by a humpback whale. The migration included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, which surprised researchers. Varvara was thought to be an endangered western gray whale, but her journey suggests she might be an eastern gray whale, indicating the need for closer examination of genetic differences between the species. With only 150 western gray whales believed to exist, this discovery could imply an even lower number.

A sudden change in the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan, occurred overnight when 1,000ft of seabed rose to the surface, creating a new stretch of land that reached up to 50ft above sea level. Geologists believe this phenomenon was caused by a landslide, where melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, lifting an underwater area into the air. The new landmass, measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, was unexpected to locals, who reported no tremors or sounds. Authorities state it is not related to the recent 7.8-magnitude earthquake in Kathmandu Valley.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports of leaving Paris Saint-Germain and stated his love for the club. He had a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped in a Champions League match. Van der Wiel expressed his happiness at PSG and desire to sign a new contract. The club is also linked with Dani Alves, and it remains uncertain whether Van der Wiel will stay.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus does not expire until the end of next season, he has indicated he wishes to leave this summer. Boca Juniors are close to completing a deal for Tevez, but he must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez, who has scored 17 goals this season, is on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus and still has a chance at European glory. Juventus have accepted his desire to leave and are identifying potential replacements. Tevez, who joined Boca's youth academy in 1996, has always intended to finish his career there. His potential move is not expected to affect his future with the Argentine national team, as his international manager, Tata Martino, emphasizes that Tevez's decision will be based on what is best for him.

Bayern Munich's manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his trousers during the Champions League match against Porto, which ended in a 6-1 victory for Bayern. The win secured Bayern's place in the semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Guardiola humorously mentioned he would need to buy new undergarments after the incident.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, and several individuals were injured. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were the first to be airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital. Later, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also transported. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, and two females escaped injuries. The highway was closed, with diversions in place south of Fernvale. Emergency crews rescued a trapped individual using hydraulic cutting gear, and a rescue helicopter transported multiple patients to hospitals. The highway is expected to remain closed for a few hours.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil has received a new Apple Watch, which he compares to the watch of the TV character Michael Knight from the show Knight Rider. Ozil is excited about the device and will use it during the Premier League match against Chelsea on Sunday. Arsenal is currently second in the league and trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. The return of Jack Wilshere has boosted Arsenal's chances, but his fitness record is a concern. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be the future of the club if he can stay fit.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite sending off three players from both teams this season, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards this season, both to United players. City captain Vincent Kompany was sent off during Belgium's match against Israel, leading to his suspension for the upcoming match against Wales. The derby is expected to be significant as it could determine who finishes second behind Chelsea. United have won their last five consecutive league games, while City have struggled since the start of the year. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing embattled MP Billy Gordon was a "little black puppet on a string" after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and admitted to a criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, said he sympathized with Gordon's position and used the term in light of his personal experiences with racism. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party and announced he would remain in the Queensland parliament as an independent, causing political chaos. Katter defended his statement, saying he used the term to highlight the racial overtones and to call out the government's assumption about Gordon's actions.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, is using her passion for dancing to challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Born with cerebral palsy, she aims to inspire others by creating videos that promote acceptance and challenge negative perceptions. Dayna has produced several videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has also begun giving motivational speeches at local schools. She hopes to encourage people to look beyond disability and recognize her as just one of them.

Orlando City have shown interest in Javier Hernandez, a Mexico international who has faced difficulties during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez could be a significant commercial draw for Orlando City due to their large Latin-American fanbase. Eight European teams, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested in Hernandez, with Manchester United willing to sell him for around £8million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to Andreas Pereira, a 19-year-old midfielder, after he rejected their initial offer. Several European clubs, including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord, have contacted Pereira's father, Marcos, regarding a potential transfer.

A group of at least three people poured gasoline on a car at a gas station in South Los Angeles and set it on fire early on Saturday morning. The driver, who was pumping gas, got into an argument with the suspects, who attempted to carjack him. The suspects covered the car in gasoline and lit it on fire while two passengers were inside. Although the car was completely ruined, no one was injured. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and surveillance video is being used in the investigation. The suspects remain at large.

A chiropractor in southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting his misdeeds and pledged not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years. Manuel's license can be reinstated only if he proves the circumstances leading to its revocation no longer exist, including bartering sex for services. Despite his misconduct, Manuel has received outstanding patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. His practice's address is listed on a residential street in Lamoni, and he has received perfect five-star ratings for patient satisfaction, though only three patient survey responses are available.

The United States has complained to Russia about a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew described the Russian pilot's actions as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers. Russian state news agency Sputnik claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder switched off, but a U.S. official denied this. This is not the first time the U.S. has raised concerns about such encounters, including a previous incident a year ago where a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk. U.S. and Russian aircraft frequently encounter each other in regions such as Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, which was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was ripped out of the car's window by breaking the rear right passenger-side window and using the momentum from another vehicle. The thief tied a rope around the rifle case and broke the handle free. The theft occurred on March 27, and the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing and tools were also stolen. The rifle has not been recovered, and the serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras, and the Secret Service was notified of the theft but could not comment on whether it affected security measures. The hotel is located near the state's FBI office.

The passage details the case of Luigi Costa, who is accused of murdering his neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Canberra. The jury has heard that Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, examined Costa and noted evidence of a declining mental state leading up to and during the attack. The prosecution claims that Costa feigned memory issues during the examination, but the psychiatrist denied these claims. The jury's verdict will depend on whether Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in a 1-0 win against Burnley, where Barkley missed the spot kick after a foul on Aaron Lennon. Although Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty record, was available, Barkley was given the responsibility. The penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton, but Everton secured the win through a goal from Mirallas. Martinez emphasized that Barkley was within his rights to take the penalty and highlighted the importance of having multiple players capable of handling such moments.

Two passengers found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam appear to have died in a murder-suicide, according to the cruise line. The deaths were discovered by cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin's door. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29. The authorities are investigating the incident, and the official determination will be made by them.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to a successful start in the 2018 World Cup qualifying process. His team advanced to the second qualifying round after a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat, with a 2-1 victory in the first leg. Kluivert, who has a connection to Curacao through his mother, has helped the team progress to the next stage, where they will face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert previously played for Holland and was an assistant coach under Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan star, has won numerous major European competitions but believes keeping Leicester City in the Premier League is as significant as winning a trophy. Leicester, currently seven points below the safety line with eight games left, faces a challenging task to avoid relegation. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester in the summer, is confident in his team's ability to secure survival and has expressed satisfaction with his new role in England. Despite not winning a game since January, he remains optimistic about the team's chances. Cambiasso's career includes success at Real Madrid and Inter Milan, and he is content in his new role at Leicester, potentially staying beyond his one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother-of-two, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children due to her ongoing addiction to legal highs and her habit of partying. Gemma handed her two infants over to her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, when they were four months old. Debbie is now threatening to ban Gemma from seeing the children after discovering her daughter's drug use and suspecting her of stealing. Debbie claims Gemma is not fit to care for the children and has been left to raise them alone after social services threatened to take them away. Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children. Debbie believes Gemma has been neglectful and irresponsible since her teenage years, leading to her current situation. She is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and the children due to her inability to trust her not to steal from them.

The passage describes a football match where Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored a goal against Manchester United. The goal came after a challenging challenge by Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, which led to a foul. Sky Sports pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul. Souness specifically mentioned that Terry used a forearm smash and an elbow to the back of Falcao's head, which resulted in Falcao falling. Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, stating that as a striker, he would have wanted a foul in that position. Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have done better to stay on his feet, Terry's challenge was still a foul.

Hillary Scott, a member of the country band Lady Antebellum, experienced a fire on their tour bus while traveling on Interstate 30 near Dallas, Texas. The fire occurred after a rear tire blew out, leading to the bus catching fire. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. Scott posted a photo of the charred bus and thanked everyone involved in ensuring their safety. The fire destroyed most of the bus's back lounge except for her Bible. The band's other members were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a physicist from Dundee University, is exploring the use of space lasers for heating homes in the future. His concept involves satellites equipped with mirrors to harvest sunlight and convert it into laser light, which can then be directed back to Earth to boost solar panel energy. While the technology is still in trial phases, initial tests in Scotland were successful, and he plans to move trials to Portugal. The system could provide solar power in Scotland or restore power quickly to disaster areas. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the potential for misuse, though he emphasizes that the lasers would not be powerful enough to be used as weapons, similar to those depicted in movies. Additionally, while Tokyo researchers have proposed using lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris, their system is not powerful enough for weaponization.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit. Munden was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, and has been missing since 6.15pm on Tuesday. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, in full view of the child's mother and grandmother. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and is described as about 5ft 8ins tall with dark hair, is believed to have shaved his beard before leaving the hospital. Officers are conducting a manhunt to locate him, as he is subject to a hospital order following his conviction for sexual offences in August. Munden admitted to ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children and was found to have children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home.

The passage discusses the legal case involving Donald Sterling, the former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, and his former female companion, V. Stiviano. After Sterling's racist remarks led to his removal from the NBA, his wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued Stiviano for $2.6 million in gifts that Sterling gave her. A Los Angeles judge ordered Stiviano to pay back the money, setting a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of gifts from a spouse's wealth. The case highlights the financial and legal consequences of Sterling's controversial behavior, including his ban from the NBA and a $2.5 million fine. The gifts included luxury items and even mundane items like an Easter bunny costume and a blender. The case also underscores the impact of Sterling's racist remarks on his personal and professional life.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to compete for the Premier League title. He believes Arsenal need to replace Olivier Giroud, despite his 14 league goals this season, as he may not be sufficient to win the league. Henry compared Arsenal's struggles to Chelsea's success last season, which led to their title win after acquiring key players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa. Arsenal are currently third in the Premier League, level with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman has testified in court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, said she was scared for her future relationships and didn't understand why she was targeted. She stated she didn't know it was wrong at the time and didn't know it was against the law. She had not spoken up about the abuse until she learned Van Ryn had been caught, after which she attempted to take her own life. The victim has suffered depression since she was 14 and has been hospitalized for self-harm and attempted suicide. She is worried about how Van Ryn's release into the community will affect her relationships with men. The hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is feeling better and closer to returning to play after over a year out due to a serious knee injury. He last played for the first team in March 2014 and has not featured since. Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s against Reading, marking his return to competitive action. He expressed that he is feeling good and is looking forward to his next game.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling down a 70ft cliff while attempting to escape a taxi driver in Penarth, South Wales. Phillips, who had caught a taxi home after a night out, did not have enough cash to pay the fare and ran from the driver. He jumped over a fence in the dark and fell down the cliff, where he was discovered the next day by a dog walker. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, stated he could not see where Phillips was going and did not realize the danger. An inquest concluded that Phillips became disoriented and was not aware of the danger, leading to his accidental death. Phillips worked for a clothing label run by Liam Gallagher and had returned to Wales for Christmas.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by the passport delay fiasco in last summer did not receive compensation, while the passport agency made a £42 million profit and managers received up to £3,500 in bonuses. Ministers refused to provide refunds, even to those who missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, called for compensation, expressing astonishment at the lack of refunds. Despite the chaos, few holidaymakers received any money back, with only one of over a dozen contacted getting compensation.

The passage describes a timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, that has remained unchanged since the 1930s and is up for sale. The property, which has been untouched for over 80 years, features original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro jars of food. It includes the original bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. The house is described as a collector's paradise with a guide price of between £200,000 and £250,000. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the house's dated features may deter developers, but it could be a perfect family home for those who appreciate antiques. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the starting quarterback for the 49ers in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He remained the team's starting quarterback for the rest of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. The passage also mentions Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95, I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, and attended Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews, and their self-titled album in 2001 was a worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo album, Everyday Robots, released on 28 April 2014, was co-produced by Richard Russell and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples from Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, known locally as Hamar. It is the location of many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut extended play, *Broken* (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two works: the 2007 film "Shooter," which follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company. It also mentions the TV series "Shooter," which stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile who is brought back into action after discovering a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that originally aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including Sharon Tate, which were carried out by members of his group at his instruction. He also received convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his convictions, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He began his acting career in television with a brief appearance in episode 112 of "Little House on the Prairie" in 1974. Penn made his film debut in "Taps" (1981) and gained critical attention for roles in "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), and "Carlito's Way" (1993). He became known for his role in "Dead Man Walking" (1995), which earned him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for "Mystic River" and a second one in 2008 for "Milk."

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in the game by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held several key leadership positions, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

The passage discusses the stance of Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the al-Wefaq opposition group in Bahrain, on the need for meaningful national dialogue. Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after several months of illness. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He worked with many leading orchestras globally and was known for his influential recordings, such as the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and later at other institutions. The passage discusses the recorded number of homicide victims in Scotland for the year ending March 2016, which was 57, the lowest since 1976 and half the figure from nine years ago. It notes that only one homicide case from 2015-16 was unresolved. The most common method of killing was a sharp instrument, accounting for 51% of homicides, with nearly all involving a knife. About 31% of accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted the continued decline in homicide and violent crime, emphasizing the need for ongoing efforts in education, enforcement, and community support. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against overinterpreting the statistics, noting previous revisions and a rise in sexual and violent crime. The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking their first loss to the Black Cats this season. Dan Gosling scored the opening goal for the Cherries, his first in three games. Manager Howe expressed disappointment, noting that the team had created multiple chances but failed to convert them. Sunderland's goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, with Bournemouth unable to score despite playing with 10 men. Howe emphasized the need to move on from the match, acknowledging that sometimes football outcomes are unpredictable.

Australia's Prime Minister, Mr. Abbott, stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referring to the policy of detaining migrants attempting to reach Australia by boat and processing them in offshore camps before resettling them elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality," while also expressing concern that European leaders should not consider adopting similar policies. Mr. Abbott acknowledged the tragic image of a Syrian child who died while attempting to reach Europe by boat but defended his policy, claiming it has stopped illegal boat arrivals. He also made controversial remarks comparing the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, which drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups. Mr. Abbott later defended his comments, stating he was not in the business of ranking evil.

The passage discusses the escalating conflict in Aleppo, Syria, where Russia and the Syrian government are accused of intensifying attacks against civilians. The United States has suspended its participation in bilateral talks with Russia, citing Russia's failure to uphold commitments and its involvement in targeting critical infrastructure and preventing humanitarian aid. Russia denies its involvement in the deadly attack on a humanitarian aid convoy and claims the incident was caused by ground fire. The US also announced it would withdraw personnel and halt the establishment of a joint implementation center, while both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to avoid conflict.

The passage discusses a report by Policy Exchange suggesting that selling high-value social homes could generate £4.5bn annually, which could fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. This would be the largest social housing program since the 1970s, according to the report. The prime minister's office supports the idea, stating that councils can already choose to sell social housing to use the funds more efficiently. However, Labour criticizes the proposal, arguing it would drive out low-income families from neighborhoods and worsen the housing crisis. The report estimates that selling expensive social housing could raise up to £159bn, with London alone holding over £70bn. Critics warn that this could lead to the segregation of communities and the displacement of the less well-off.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week in Swansea, a city affected by a measles outbreak with 942 cases. The cause of death could not be determined during the examination, and an inquest will be held to investigate further. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams was treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and later developed a rash. He visited an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a rash but not on his arms. He was found dead the next day. Public Health Wales confirmed a measles diagnosis, but further tests are needed to establish the cause of death. The family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close family members have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offence involving an attack on a boy under 16, according to Cumbria Police. The incident is reported to have occurred in 2001, and Mr. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In the match between Gateshead and Guiseley, both teams had strong performances. Guiseley scored first on the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor after a throw-in from James Hurst. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York. The game ended in a 1-1 draw. Both teams had notable substitutions during the match, and there were yellow card incidents involving Simon Walton and Gus Mafuta.

Bristol Sport Ltd aims to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed by a town green application. The redevelopment plans were approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club will begin work if the judicial review period is cleared by March, with the redevelopment starting in May.

Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling, has suspended operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, near Poulton-le-Fylde. The company will review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume drilling. The BGS noted that the tremor shared a similar location and mechanism with a previous one. Shale gas drilling, or fracking, involves fracturing shale rocks to release gas. Cuadrilla's CEO emphasized the company's responsibility and the need for consultation with authorities. The process has been controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, but the UK's energy select committee supports it with proper regulation. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, noting that injecting water into rocks can cause earthquakes.
