Two small earthquakes have occurred in Lancashire since fracking began in March, including the latest one. The BGS analyzed the April quake, stating that injection of water during extraction processes can result in earthquake activity. The tremor occurred 1.2 miles from the drilling site, and the BGS confirmed its location and depth.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, denied three counts of fraud but was found guilty of one count for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of the other two counts by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Carpenter claimed he was busking and that the banner was a tribute to the victims, not for fundraising. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, stated he gave permission for the banner but clarified it was not for collecting funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward opened the scoring with a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney scoring after QPR's keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Cole Skuse then scored with a long-range shot, and Tom Lawrence added the third goal with a calm finish. Despite opportunities, QPR struggled offensively, and their keeper was criticized for a poor clearance that allowed Varney to score. Ipswich improved to 14th place, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his players, particularly Luke Varney, and expressed hope for a more confident team. QPR manager Ian Holloway criticized his team's performance, blaming the second goal and the mental toughness of his players.

Wells, 23, had a strong performance in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's direction and the positive environment created by the coaches, which motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, ranked fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were highlighted for their leadership and performance, with the team making over 70 tackles. The Reds have seven games against teams below them in the table and will face league leaders Old Elthamians next. Churcher emphasized the need to build on their performance, stating that a lack of improvement could make last weekend's win a waste.

The police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. The incident caused outrage in India and led to protests. This is the sixth arrest in the crime, with eight suspects identified, two still untraced. Five previously arrested individuals named Nazrul as the rapist. Police arrested Milon Sarkar in May, describing him as the leader of the gang. During the attack on 14 March in Ranaghat, money was stolen from the convent school, and the building was ransacked before the rape occurred.

The passage discusses an interactive video that may not work on older browsers, with a non-interactive version available. The video features Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explaining reasons for changing consumer habits, such as the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also explores changes in brand ownership and ranking in the UK. Additional resources include links to articles on what China owns, freezing food tips, and the top 20 consumer brands in the UK.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and a woman from Stranraer were both victims of scams where callers impersonated BT technical support to gain remote access to their computers and steal money. The incidents occurred on 15 September and seven days later, respectively. PC Siobhan Pellett warned that these scams are concerning due to the ease of access and the significant amounts of money involved. She emphasized that people should be cautious when responding to cold calls asking to resolve alleged faults and never provide banking details or account numbers over the telephone, as reputable organizations never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined the third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his successful tenure at Swinton. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The rider was found with head injuries and was very cold after lying unconscious on wet sand. She received treatment and was subsequently flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, aiming to enhance the current system that relies on ground-based radars. The decision was prompted by the disappearance of flight MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will allow satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft globally. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) are working to implement these changes, with the ICAO setting a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez, a boy who disappeared at age five, is now 18 and living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, has been arrested and is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. The FBI, along with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity after receiving a tip on 30 October related to his college application issues. Bobby is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Authorities suspected Bobby was involved in Julian's disappearance, as he was seen taking his son to preschool in August 2002 before fleeing. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

Firefighters responded to a blaze on 2 March at the site on Duncan Street, leading to several days of investigation and reduced train services. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire, despite the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. The company can appeal the decision until 7 August. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the site nine times in the last 12 months, raising concerns about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment. The EA, after considering the facts, decided to revoke the environmental permit, which will take effect on 7 August unless appealed. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia. The first bill is linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly the Crimea region, where pro-Russian sentiments are strong. It aims to allow Russia to accept territories whose people express a clear desire to join Russia, even if the neighboring state has not signed a treaty. The second bill speeds up the process for issuing Russian passports, allowing Ukrainians to apply for Russian citizenship without paying taxes, having previous residency in Russia, or sufficient funds. The bills are part of Russia's response to the crisis in Ukraine, with support from Russian MPs and celebrities in Crimea.

McLaren, with a rich history of 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a downturn in performance. The team has two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, and is facing challenges primarily due to the Honda power-unit. The team's decline began in 2013 and has been attributed to issues with the Honda engine. McLaren's history includes periods of dominance and decline, with notable successes in the 1980s and 2000s. Despite recent struggles, Ron Dennis believes the team is on the path to recovery and is confident that success will return, with Alonso's return in 2015 being a key factor. The team is currently in a period of slow decline, but Dennis is optimistic about the future.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. He was shot in the head and chest and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29, and 32, were arrested and remain in police custody. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the attack. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene quickly, traveling through several roads. CCTV footage from the area is being reviewed, and authorities are urging people to come forward with any information they may have.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas in a spiritual manner without giving up on gadgets. It highlights Everyday Church Online, a virtual church service that allows people from around the world to participate in Sunday services. The service includes a chat room and has attracted participants from 61 countries. The first Christmas theme is based on Star Wars, with sermons exploring themes of hope. Another example is Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play fantasy game for children that encourages them to rediscover biblical stories. The passage also mentions a viral Christmas video, "The Digital Story of Nativity," and a Christmas ad by the Churches Advertising Network that was rejected by some cinemas for being too religious. Additionally, Next Manga has created a Christmas-themed book in the form of Manga, which is available in multiple languages and has been distributed to refugees. The passage concludes by noting how various groups are using social media platforms to connect with their communities and share spiritual messages.

A hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to develop 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts provided conflicting accounts regarding the impact on habitats and plant life, with Natural Resources Wales finding it difficult to conclude the replacement land is of equal value but not opposing the development. An ecology report suggested a "net gain" in biodiversity due to nearby habitat enhancements, which the Gwent wildlife trust opposed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend on the matter, with the Welsh government making the final decision.

The passage discusses the response of Chechen Muslim clerics to a report by Novaya Gazeta, which accused Chechen authorities of targeting homosexual men. The clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and called for retribution against the true instigators. The report revealed that over 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report and stated that detainees were tortured. Ramzan Kadyrov, the authoritarian leader, denied the allegations, claiming there were no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader also supported the idea of retribution. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor emphasized that the report did not insult the Chechen people and urged dialogue. The LGBT Network is assisting those fleeing persecution and is considering legal action against Russia if it fails to prosecute those responsible.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, have been involved in a controversy over their arrangement with housing benefit payments. Investing Solutions finds properties for single homeless men and charges more than the rent passed on to private landlords, making the arrangement profitable. The charity, Fresh Start Housing, refers clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. The two organizations are based in the same building in south London. Investing Solutions was set up in 2002 and is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, operating across seven London boroughs. A tenant, Nigel McCann, described the properties as unsuitable, with issues like lack of heating, rats, and damp. The council has paid over £2.1m to Investing Solutions. Critics, including a homeless charity, called the relationship a "new low." Samir Patel, founder of Investing Solutions, stated that Fresh Start Housing is an independent charity and that the majority of rents are passed to private landlords. The charity said it housed 788 homeless people since its founding and 222 in the last 12 months. The Department for Communities and Local Government said local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money.

In the game, London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters but were overhauled by the Netherlands in the last 10 minutes. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, won the game 71-60. GB will now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the importance of completing every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor. Gordon, who joined the team despite missing out on a spot in London 2012, had a good performance, particularly in the third quarter.

The former five-weight world champion submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) on Wednesday, hours before the deadline. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, expected to receive a request from McGregor on Wednesday. NAC rules state fights at 154 lbs require 10oz gloves, and the matter will be debated on 16 August. Lighter gloves offer less cushioning but can lead to more punishing punches. Mayweather had not submitted a waiver document when he posted about using 8oz gloves, and the NAC executive director, Bob Bennett, said he had never seen a move to 8oz gloves at 154lbs before. The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision. McGregor, 29, will make his boxing debut in what could be the richest fight in history. The UFC lightweight champion's move from the octagon to the ring to face Mayweather, 40, has prompted criticism from major boxing personalities. Bennett studied a "litany of information" on McGregor and considered factors such as his UFC rival Nate Diaz, who he believed was an outstanding boxer. Bennett said McGregor's progress and his granite-like chin, along with his height and age, were reasons to approve the fight. McGregor floored Diaz three times in a 2016 fight, and Bennett has had access to three videos showing McGregor's progress, telling BBC Sport he's good to go. He also advised McGregor's camp to employ a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Hall of Fame official Joe Cortez, who oversaw an "out of control" sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi. The former two-weight world champion has since left the camp after reacting angrily to images of him on the canvas during a sparring session.

The passage discusses the closure of the London office of the Dundee-based Sunday Post, marking the end of an era for Fleet Street, historically the heart of British journalism. Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post, reflect on the changing landscape of journalism, with the decline of traditional print media and the rise of digital platforms. Fleet Street was once a hub for newspapers, with many national and provincial publications having offices within a short distance. The area was known for its vibrant journalism culture, including a strong social scene and a history of journalistic tradition. The closure of the Sunday Post's London office symbolizes the end of an era, as the traditional print media industry declines. The passage also highlights the historical significance of Fleet Street, its role in the development of British journalism, and the transition to more modern forms of media. It mentions the decline of Fleet Street due to the move of major newspapers to other parts of London and the adoption of new technologies. The story concludes with a reflection on the legacy of Fleet Street and the ongoing impact of its history on the current media landscape.

J.K. Rowling expressed that her comments on Twitter reminded her of the large number of decent people in the world. She previously stated that her "personal line [had] been crossed" by abusive comments and emphasized standing up to bullies. Rowling faced criticism on Twitter for donating £1m to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and for blocking abusive users she believed supported the Scottish National Party (SNP). She stated she has no responsibility to silence such behavior to protect political parties' images. Despite this, she engaged with some SNP supporters and shared political commonalities. A Twitter user suggested her books should be burned, to which she jokingly responded by saying she would "bring marshmallows." The SNP won 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland and is now the third largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers on youth crime and poverty in Scotland. It found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls, with boys being three times more likely to engage in violent acts than girls. Poorer young people are also five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. The study highlights a destructive dynamic where poverty increases the risk of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system can exacerbate poverty. The findings were published in the Scottish Justice Matters journal, and the study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998. The Scottish government claims Scotland is becoming a safer place to live, with crime at a 41-year low, but the study also shows that crime remains concentrated in the most deprived areas, raising questions about addressing inequality.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. At Ennis District Court, it was alleged that Mr. Walsh and two other men entered the Marian Estate shortly after 01:00 on Sunday, seeking Mr. Haugh. They encountered Mr. Haugh and another man, leading to a fight where weapons were used. During the altercation, Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back and was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. A knife with blood on it was recovered at the scene. A judge noted the state's evidence of tension in the area and remanded Mr. Walsh in custody until 14 August.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP, during a BBC radio interview in May 2014. The tweet questioned Elliott's past actions, but it was later deleted within an hour. The High Court was informed that the tweet was untrue and without foundation, and Flanagan apologized. The court reserved judgment on compensation, while the insurance firm covering MLAs refused to cover Flanagan, leading to a separate legal challenge. Tom Elliott expressed disappointment but felt vindicated after the resolution.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees and a history dating back to 1874, has increased its sweater production to 9,500 per week to meet rising demand. This growth is attributed to strong sales of its new branded range, launched in January, and increased orders from both its private label clients and its own brand. The company, purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, sells its products in Europe and markets outside Europe, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop expressed confidence in the company's future, citing the dedication of its staff as a key factor in its success.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, while she was on duty as a lollipop lady outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, admitted striking her but claims he was blinded by the setting sun. The incident occurred when Wright failed to stop for a red light, leading to the collision. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions and described the incident as turning Blackburn's "world upside down." The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a NATO exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, U33, which is trying to avoid detection. The exercise highlights concerns about Russia's increasing military strength, with Russia now having a fleet of around 60 submarines, including the latest "quietest submarine in the world." The exercise also showcases the use of underwater drones and anti-submarine warfare helicopters. The passage emphasizes the challenges of detecting submarines and the need for improved defenses, particularly in Britain, which no longer has its own maritime patrol aircraft, leaving it vulnerable to potential Russian submarine threats.

The passage discusses the ongoing ethnic violence in South Sudan, which has led to a significant number of people fleeing to Uganda. Since the violence began in July, over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, the highest number in the country this year. The violence, which is ethnic-based, has resulted in killings, rape, and the targeting of civilians. The conflict started as a civil war between the Dinka President Salva Kiir and former Vice-President Riek Machar, but the violence against Equatorians began in July when rebel troops fled the capital. Uganda is handling the influx of refugees well, with aid agencies helping to set up shelters and provide resources. However, the situation is becoming increasingly difficult as the number of refugees grows, and there are concerns about the long-term sustainability of the aid efforts. The passage also highlights the resilience of the refugees, as seen in the story of a 16-year-old girl who performed a poem about the trauma of war.

McKenzie, 38, will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. He became a professional boxer in 2013 after leaving football two years prior, with a record of eight wins and one draw in nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the funding and construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of a £330m investment by a coalition for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped, leading to issues with temperature and maintenance. The project's total cost is £33m, with the remaining funds coming from NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Matron Sue Taylor and Dr. Donal Hynes highlight the need for a modern facility to improve patient care and the hospital's environment. The new hospital is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with an expected completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was either in or near a black Mercedes car when he was shot. Officers arrived at 13:35 GMT and found him with a gunshot wound to his chest. He was taken to Northern General Hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents mentioned he was part of a family gathering for a celebration when the attack occurred. There have been several shootings in Sheffield recently, with previous incidents in the north of the city, not near Upperthorpe. Other incidents include a 25-year-old man shot in Shiregreen, an elderly couple shot through their window in Southey Green, and shots fired at houses in High Green.

The passage discusses the role of various cyber groups in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. It highlights the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, who engage in cyber warfare activities such as DDoS attacks, hacking into Russian servers, and printing pro-Ukrainian messages on network printers. They also monitor rebel-held areas using hijacked CCTV systems. The group claims to have provided data to Ukraine's security service, though officials deny using hacked information for military operations. On the other side, Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has hacked Ukrainian government websites, released propaganda, and disrupted election systems. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked documents from the Kremlin and has also covered Ukraine-related issues. The passage also mentions the involvement of various cyber groups in the conflict, including their methods and objectives.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several Scottish Parliament members before the election on 5 May. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotionally moved by the speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity and the importance of a strong, united parliament, while also expressing concerns about the Scotland Bill not fulfilling unionist political promises. McNeil warned Holyrood about the need to learn from Westminster's committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also stepped down, joking about missing interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The review will gather experiences from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of including the voices of older people and those who care for them, highlighting both the positive impact of high-quality care and the issues arising from poor care. Her team will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will also engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review but expresses disappointment that no care home expert is on the advisory panel, stating that this misses an opportunity for partnership working.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit of £3.5m for the year to the end of June 2016, an increase of £800,000, despite a £1m drop in turnover to over £100m. The company noted growth in international sales, both in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies animal feeds for various sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, offering products for farming and rural communities. The company expressed confidence in its ability to navigate challenges, including the impact of Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. A man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Detectives are investigating the death, which is being treated as murder, and want to question Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, a 55-year-old man described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying, straight, collar-length hair, and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. The police are urging anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers. Officers are conducting additional patrols in the area.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, highlighted the risks of a weakening global economy in a speech, noting that the IMF's latest assessment shows a declining baseline. He emphasized the delicate situation, following weaker-than-expected Chinese trade figures, which saw exports drop by a quarter year-on-year. The IMF is expected to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% in April. The situation has ongoing implications for businesses and industries reliant on China's growth.

The passage discusses issues with a new ferry service launching on 14 May, which has faced multiple problems including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension due to training issues. The council has decided to offer free crossings until 2 July to address these problems and gather feedback. A review by auditors has been ordered. Local businesses, such as Valu-4-U, are experiencing significant losses, and there is discussion about potential compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledges the challenges but states the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems, which have been addressed, including electrical issues and vehicle ramp extensions.

A crash involving multiple vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was declared dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while investigators examined the scene.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Matching Models, an international temp agency in London, which advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, including a "classic look, brown long hair with B-c cup." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) criticized the agency for its "appalling, unlawful and demeaning" practices, stating that such ads violate equality legislation. Campaigners compared the ads to the 1970s, highlighting the discriminatory nature of the requirements. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, arguing that "looks are important" and that clients have specific aesthetic preferences. However, employment lawyer James Lynas argued that the use of such descriptions is unlawful and could lead to discrimination claims. The EHRC and other equality organizations called for the agency to revise its practices. The passage also mentions other job ads, such as one for a "sexy female driver," and highlights that Matching Models has clients in various industries, including MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school. He shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and was remanded until 12 April. Incidents of gun crime at schools and colleges in India are rare, though India has strict control laws. In 2007, a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students at a school near Delhi.

Glaad analyzed television shows from June 2016 to May 2017 and found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with the number of transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. Over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study focused on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported that millions of pounds in public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished, with about £10.25m now missing and the loan under a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities." Mackintosh denied any wrongdoing and had previously stated his intention to run for re-election. However, he decided it was the right time for his constituents to have a new representative. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him.

In April, Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The incident occurred after police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Officers were inside the home when they heard what they believed to be gunshots, leading Oliver to fire into the car, which was driving away. The police officer involved was later fired for policy violations. Oliver faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted of murder, which would be the first such conviction in Dallas County since 1973. The case is ongoing, with no trial date set. The Edwards family's lawyer expressed caution, noting the long gap since a police officer was convicted of murder in Texas.

The president-elect has indicated that Mrs. Trump and Barron will move to Washington "very soon, after he's finished with school," but has not provided a specific date. The decision has sparked mixed reactions, with some criticizing the move as inappropriate, while others support it, noting that it aligns with the priorities of a responsible parent. The decision is not entirely unprecedented, as there have been other first ladies who did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. The role of the first lady is primarily ceremonial, involving hosting events and supporting causes, though some have taken on more active roles. Melania Trump's focus on tackling cyberbullying is one of her potential priorities. The White House can be shaped by the family, and previous first ladies have balanced their roles with family life, maintaining a sense of normalcy.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October this year. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been tasked with investigating the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is fully engaged with the investigation and is awaiting the findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed the Pirc to conduct the investigation, and a report on the findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course.

The passage describes a yellow wind warning issued, with gusts up to 75mph (120km/h) expected, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction is noted as contributing to the wind's impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is anticipated. The affected areas include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell on Menai Bridge, closing a main route into the town, and Telford Road is expected to remain closed most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants and Panthers had a back-and-forth game where the Giants got a short-handed opener through player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. Mike Forney's powerplay goal gave the Giants a 2-1 lead, which Andy Bohmback equalized. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, making it 4-2 in favor of the Giants, before Nottingham's David Ling scored to make it 4-3. The teams will face each other again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid, suffered a broken front wing on the first lap, and made five pit stops. He faces a 36-point deficit to Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races of the season. Sebastian Vettel finished second after a collision with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen recovered to fifth, passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Ferrari's decision to use soft tyres for the final stint gave Raikkonen an advantage over Hamilton, who struggled to overtake Felipe Massa. Hamilton expressed confidence in closing the points gap, as no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to win the championship. The race was marked by multiple incidents on the first lap, leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Hamilton and Raikkonen had already pitted once to replace damaged front wings. Ricciardo took the lead from Rosberg but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to take the lead. Mercedes did not stop Ricciardo under the safety car, and Rosberg eventually took the lead. Hamilton struggled to recover after multiple pit stops and faces an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning his first world title.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, came out publicly to advance discussions on a topic that was "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement received widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures, including Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball and former German Football Association president Theo Zwanziger. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a significant step in the fight against homophobia in football, especially in Germany, which has struggled with the issue. His announcement is considered a watershed moment, encouraging others to come out and promoting greater openness about sexuality in the sport. Previous examples of German footballers coming out include Marcus Urban in 2007, while former Germany captain Philipp Lahm had expressed views against gay footballers coming out. Hitzlsperger's courage has been praised by various figures, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck, who hope his announcement will help break down the taboo around homosexuality in football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, contributing to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract set to expire, he is seeking a new deal. Brighton's recent victory over Wigan secured their promotion, and they currently lead by four points, aiming to win the league title in their final two matches. Sidwell, who previously played for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, has been pivotal for Brighton and believes he deserves the opportunity to continue playing at the top level. He expressed confidence in securing a new contract during the summer.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in a closely contested match. Blackpool took the lead early when Nathan Delfouneso passed the ball to Jamille Matt, who scored from close range. Colchester equalized after a goalmouth scramble, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring. Blackpool had chances to win, including a goal-scoring opportunity from Tom Aldred, but he headed the ball wide. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston and may debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The passage discusses the construction of a permanent memorial for police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty. PC Keith Palmer's murder in March prompted the need for such a memorial, leading the UK Police Memorial Trust to seek £1.5m for its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial will honor over 1,400 officers and staff, with a brass screen featuring leaf shapes given to families. The government has committed £1m of the £4m needed, with the memorial expected to be completed by 2019. Home Secretary Amber Rudd emphasized the importance of remembering those who give their lives in the line of duty.

The passage discusses Manchester United's strong position in the Premier League, remaining 15 points clear at the top with eight games left. After a 1-0 win at Sunderland, Ferguson emphasized focusing on future games, noting the team's record of 25 wins in their first 30 matches. The team has a 15-point headstart over Manchester City in the next derby. Ferguson also mentioned injuries to key players and potential changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. The team's win was attributed to strong defense and courage, despite a challenging second half against Sunderland.

Mr. Schmidt stated that Google paid the legally required amount of UK corporate taxes, having paid £10m between 2006 and 2011. He emphasized that taxes are legally required and that companies must comply with the law. If the UK changes its tax laws, Google will adapt accordingly. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested establishing a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, allowing for secret hearings to ensure transparency. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, is criticized for minimizing UK tax payments. The EU agreed to implement an automatic information exchange to monitor tax avoidance. Mr. Schmidt also argued that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are conducted, not where products are consumed, and called for international tax reform. He believes politicians should set the rules and that companies should abide by the law.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the agency bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year, following a £3.6bn expenditure last year. A cap of 55% above normal shift rates for agency staff has saved £600m, with senior managers exempt. The regulator is concerned the NHS is still short of its goals, with trusts 10% below target. While agency costs are decreasing, other pay expenses may be rising. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trusts on agency spending and investigate high earnings for agency staff, finding instances of excessive rates. The chief executive emphasized the NHS's financial constraints regarding expensive agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger economic boom, now stands as a monument to the economic crash in the Republic of Ireland. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, report a decline in business, though they see signs of recovery through diversification into childrenswear and dress-hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for not adequately supporting the midlands, suggesting investments should focus on broadband rather than water meters. The government, however, highlights the upcoming Center Parcs development as a potential boost to the local economy. Despite this, traders believe more support is needed, particularly in areas like parking charges and targeted investment to stimulate further economic growth.

The competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium. Eight teams participate, each facing each other twice, with the top four teams qualifying for the play-offs. The leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). The most sixes are by Warner (12) and De Villiers (12), with Kohli (8). The highest individual score in an innings is De Kock (108), Warner (90*), and Gambhir (90*). The most wickets are by McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The fixtures and results are available on BBC Sport. The tournament includes a series of matches with specific dates and times. The final is scheduled for 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, highlighting the environmental issues caused by non-recyclable bags that end up in landfills and rivers. To address this, England will implement a 5p charge on plastic bags starting in October to encourage reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have led to reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope the English charge will help reduce waste and protect the environment.

A school roof was ripped off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, while hundreds of homes across Wales experienced power cuts. The day saw train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts for hundreds of homes. A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind was in effect until midnight on Friday. Friday was one of the busiest days of the festive season on UK roads. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, transferring passengers to their cruise ferry services. Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and possible delays between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has caused at least one festive event to be postponed - Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip will now go ahead on Tuesday, 27 December. Check if this is affecting your journey.

Jordan is excited to reunite with Ryan Coogler, the director of Creed, and work with actors such as Oscar-winning actress Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who is starring as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The film will feature Jordan in an unspecified role and is set to be released in February 2018.

The passage discusses the restoration of Alexandra Palace, including the theatre founded in 1875, which is intended for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios at the palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The project aims to transform the palace into a new cultural destination, with the east wing restoration costing £26.6m, supported by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m) and Haringey Council (£6.8m), with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust raising the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, which has not been used for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery and was originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings. If successful, the theatre is hoped to reopen in 2018.

The former Manchester City player, 30, earned 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was part of two World Cup and two European Championship squads but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, making his debut in 2004. He scored his first and only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family were awakened by her son David to find their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, on fire. The family managed to escape, but their house was destroyed, and their dog and cats did not survive. The fire was caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, something Mrs Smith had done many times before. The fire alarm did not go off. The family fled wearing only pajamas, but the community supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and even a bike for David. Mrs Smith expressed her pride in David for saving her and her daughter.

The passage discusses the potential £200m offer by an energy drinks company for the Premier League club West Ham. Sullivan and Gold purchased a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m, now owning over 85% of the club. Since moving to London Stadium in August, West Ham has been linked with potential takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to reduce debts, but he and Gold intended the ownership to pass to their children.

The passage describes a red carpet event in Los Angeles that was not the Oscars but featured fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance, with Efron winning the latter. The event also served as an unofficial promotional platform for this summer's blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for his role in American Sniper. Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for her role in Into the Woods. Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne were also among the winners. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his kids, and Robert Downey Jr accepted the Generation Award with his fellow Avengers stars. Clips from upcoming films were shown during the event.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old player, was loaned to St Mirren from Dundee United in July. This season, Smith has scored five goals. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the club. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised Smith as a good player and a mature individual who will be a good fit for the team, providing an additional option in the attacking area. St Mirren will host Falkirk in their next match.

Northumberland County Council has stated that the weather is now warm enough for their Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes. The council aims to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be working on repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016, where six workers from Wood Group were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while performing shutdown work. The workers reported being exposed to alpha radiation without proper personal protective equipment (PPE), as they were told the area was safe. EnQuest confirmed the incident and stated that the exposure level was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). Additional precautionary steps were taken to ensure safety. The workers are now undergoing blood tests and have expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects, including cancer. EnQuest and Wood Group both emphasized their commitment to employee safety, while the Unite union criticized the handling of the incident. The HSE noted the incident was not reportable under current regulations and no separate investigation was conducted.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The allegations of the dealer selling stolen artifacts were revealed during a 2012 court case. The museum returned the sculpture after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return in May. The museum noted that while there is no conclusive proof of the sculpture's theft, the dealer's confession about dealing in looted artifacts was taken into account. The museum will take legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with tremors felt as far as Milan and Florence. There were no immediate injuries or damage reported. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a major quake in L'Aquila in 2009 causing 300 deaths. The National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) reported the quake occurred at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) with its epicentre in Garfagnana, and several smaller aftershocks were felt. Phone lines and power were cut in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. The quake was described as a classic earthquake for the region, being medium-strong and fairly shallow. Last May, two earthquakes in the same area resulted in over 20 deaths. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted for providing misleading information about the risk of an earthquake before the 2009 disaster, leading to deaths.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield observed a fruit still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. Despite his initial doubts about South Yorkshire's climate, he was delighted with the results. "I was literally jumping for joy," the 62-year-old grandfather said.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the game until 24 March 2024, originally scheduled for 27 January. The delay is due to additional testing and polishing to ensure quality. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. Screenshots of the PC version of GTA V show enhanced details, with Los Santos and Blaine County visible in 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor setups. Minimum system requirements for running GTA V have been published. Grand Theft Auto V was the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its 2013 release.

The 76-year-old artist, who won the £25,000 prize for the painting "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991. Simpson, who has made the prize longlist on three other occasions, described winning as "very nice indeed." Judge Ansel Krut praised "Squint (19)" as "quite extraordinary," noting it was a "difficult painting to look at." The painting depicts a leper squint, a historical feature in medieval churches. Simpson entered the painting due to its relatively small size and because he was working on it. The prize money will be used for materials like stretches, canvas, and high-quality paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake is the current patron of the prize and won the junior title in 1961.

The passage reports that the offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by four masked assailants, resulting in no casualties. The attacks occurred early on Thursday, with both buildings experiencing shattered windows and numerous spent bullet casings. The two newspapers support the ruling AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The police have cordoned off the area and are investigating the incident. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. This follows a similar incident in September where pro-government protesters attacked Hurriyet, accusing it of misquoting the president.

A 24-year-old player was under contract with the Stags but has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. The player spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. He will officially join on 1 January and becomes Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger, whose contract with the club runs until the summer, has been linked with the managerial role. Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce in September, has led England to a 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and ability to observe the national team. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to convince the FA to offer him a permanent role. Wenger emphasized the importance of a manager's competency over fame. Additionally, Wenger mentioned that defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, despite speculation about his transfer. Midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels. The RMT union claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The change will see contracted services return to Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, previously operated by Seatruck, will now be managed under the new arrangement. Seatruck argued the national minimum wage did not apply to non-UK residents, but Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap, which Seatruck declined. The new arrangements will come into effect early next month after finalizing financial and regulatory details. All crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, awarded the Northern Isles contract in 2012, operates three ferries and two cargo boats on a heavily subsidized route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, leading to a confrontation. The trial revealed that Mr. Mitchell and his mother, Samantha, 57, had lied to police about the events, initially claiming Mr. Dickie had pushed Mrs. Mitchell, but later stating they tried to separate the couple, resulting in a "tragic accident." Both Mitchell and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice. They pleaded guilty to common assault and will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter and musician, passed away at the age of 66 in London after a brief battle with cancer. He is best known for writing hits such as "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Rock With You" for Michael Jackson, as well as "Boogie Nights" for the band Heatwave. Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man," was influenced by his father's love for music, which started him listening to Radio Luxembourg as a child. He worked as a keyboardist for Heatwave in the 1970s, and his songs became hits for the band. His work with Quincy Jones led to his contributions to Michael Jackson's breakthrough albums Off The Wall and Thriller, which helped make Thriller the best-selling album of all time. Temperton also won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars. He was celebrated for his songwriting philosophy of writing songs he loved first. Temperton's passing has been mourned by many in the music industry, including Michael Jackson's sister, Nile Rodgers, and Mark Ronson. His private funeral has taken place, and his family has requested total privacy.

Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, along with researchers from the universities of Exeter, Reading, and Brazil's São Paulo and Belém, discovered ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazil, possibly 2,000 years old. These earthworks, concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest, were revealed due to modern deforestation and include over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs." The function of these sites is unclear, but they are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures, and may have been used as ritual gathering places. Dr. Loader analyzed soil samples and found that the geoglyphs were constructed among taller vegetation, suggesting they were not visible above the forest canopy. The research challenges the assumption that the Amazon was pristine before European contact, indicating that humans have been influencing the environment for thousands of years, possibly through agroforestry practices. The study suggests that the biodiversity in Acre's remaining forests may retain a legacy of these ancient practices.

Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round. Ranked 12th in the world, Kyrgios recently won the Japan Open and is approaching the top 10. He mentioned feeling tired and bored during the match, attributing his lack of usual vocal energy to fatigue and the demanding travel schedule, including the journey to the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai. Kyrgios had previously been fined $1,500 for a harsh outburst at the Shanghai Masters.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of the HPV vaccine in preventing head and neck cancers, with scientists and charities advocating for its rollout in Wales. The vaccine, which is sexually transmitted, is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. Charities and researchers are urging the government to vaccinate boys to address the rising number of head and neck cancer cases, which are increasingly affecting younger individuals, mostly men. In 2008, a vaccination programme was introduced in schools, resulting in 85% of girls in Wales being vaccinated. The Welsh government has stated it will consider any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination programme after receiving the committee's recommendations.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, was diagnosed with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma in August. Despite his illness, he remained positive and documented his journey on social media through a page called "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 likes. He attended a school prom in his honor on Saturday, though he had to leave due to feeling unwell. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. On January 23, doctors informed Jak's family that his cancer had spread, and they decided not to pursue further treatment. Jak expressed his gratitude to those who helped him and urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. He also shared personal moments, including visits to his classmates, playing his tuba, and attending events with friends and celebrities. A special football match is expected to raise more money for charity. Jak's mother, Allison, shared the news of his passing on his Facebook page, expressing her deep sadness and pride in him.

Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda in a match that was largely uneventful until the 89th minute, when Mohamed Salah set up Abdallah El Said to score the winning goal. The win means Egypt will face Ghana in the next match for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament for the first time since 1978. Ghana had already secured a 1-0 win over Mali, ensuring their place in the quarter-finals. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch, with Uganda forcing Egypt's goalkeeper Essam El Hadary to make several saves. Despite Uganda's efforts, they failed to score, and Egypt's late goal came from a well-executed play by Salah and El Said. Uganda now faces Mali in their final group game, with a win and a Ghana-Egypt result of 2-0 or more needed for qualification.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a study by Network Rail. The decision includes a site near the Concourse shopping centre. Skelmersdale's original railway station closed in 1956, and the town does not have its own railway station. The council plans to partner with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council to provide two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The chosen site is considered suitable for future expansion and has good highway access and connectivity. Skelmersdale was designated a new town in 1961 and is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police found plants in an "elaborate grow house." A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found lying on a pavement with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent an emergency operation and was transported to a specialist clinic. The suspect, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, handed himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The study, conducted by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed data from 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but less likely to receive one. The research refuted the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking for higher pay due to fear of upsetting their boss or adhering to female stereotypes. The study compared full-time male and female workers, finding that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The research also noted that differences in age groups showed that women and men under 40 had similar rates of asking for and receiving pay rises, suggesting a shift in negotiation behavior. The study, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, indicated possible discrimination against women, with researchers suggesting that negotiation behavior may be changing, particularly for younger women.

Oxford City Council has explored various options for a new burial site but has not found any suitable land. Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to search for a suitable site, having identified and discounted several council-owned sites due to factors such as size, ground conditions, high water tables, or covenants. Once the cemeteries are full, the council will only allow the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to access online information, including videos, band interviews, and details about signs and posters on the site. The festival is introducing an augmented reality experience to enhance the visitor's enjoyment and allow people worldwide to interact with the event and experience its atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated in the run-up to and during the festival, enabling instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the unique festival experience from anywhere. This year's acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He was treated by veterinary staff and was pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, noted that such incidents are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. He had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past but had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on the day of the race. The report concludes that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage, not linked to his previous health issues.

The passage details the case of Davina Ayrton, who was accused of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in the autumn of 2004. Ayrton, now 34, denied the charge and is set to be sentenced on 3 March. Judge Ian Pearson ordered her remand into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester, citing concerns about her risk to herself and failure to attend court. The case involved Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide in the summer, and the victim, who described the attack while her friends were asleep. The victim had consumed alcohol and recalled the events. Ayrton also disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss followed Djokovic's surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July to Sam Querrey. Djokovic, the world number one, had previously won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, will feature over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. The competition involves carving logs into shapes of animals and people using only chainsaws, with no other tools allowed. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb has not played since suffering a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is close to a return and is currently in a pre-season stage, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations in February. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign against Ireland on 7 February. Webb, a 27-year-old capped 16 times by Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. He has chosen to stay with Ospreys, where he made his debut in 2007, as it is his home region and he enjoys the club.

A group of individuals were arrested in an attempt to smuggle 58 pounds (26kg) of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. US border agents encountered two men near the border, leading to a confrontation where one man dropped his backpack, fired a weapon, and fled. The other man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. Canadian and US police searched for the fugitive and eventually arrested Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who were involved in planning to transport the drugs. The three defendants face charges including conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling, and the US attorney's office emphasizes that drug smuggling prosecutions are a significant part of their work.

The NSPCC's Childline service counseled over 4,500 children in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity highlights that the number of children suffering online abuse is much higher. Some children as young as seven have experienced torment, abuse, and fear of going to school. Online trolls cause significant misery and humiliation for many children. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasizes the need for intervention from adults, parents, and teachers to protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own and can worsen. The report is released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which works with parents, schools, and other organizations to address the issue. A young person shared their experience of online bullying, including being told to kill themselves, and expressed feelings of distress and a lack of understanding from their parents. Advice for dealing with bullying includes seeking help and not isolating oneself.

The passage discusses the US decision to abstain from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The resolution, which condemned the establishment of settlements as illegal under international law, was passed despite Israel's rejection. Netanyahu responded by recalling ambassadors, cutting aid, and canceling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on new settlement homes at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further tensions with the US ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, seeing it as a step toward the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage discusses the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, including a BBC interview where she is praised as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. Events included a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, a ceremony in Alexandra Gardens, and the release of stamps celebrating the Queen and her family. Prince William acknowledges his own role as a future heir and addresses criticism of his work ethic. The Queen and Prince Philip will walk around Windsor and unveil a plaque, and the Queen will light a beacon. The passage also mentions republican criticism of the extensive coverage of the Queen's birthday.

In the match between Cheltenham and West Ham United, West Ham secured a 2-0 victory. The first half saw West Ham take an early lead with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham had chances but could not convert them. The match ended with Cheltenham's exit from the EFL Cup, marking the end of League Two's representation in the competition. Despite opportunities, Cheltenham could not find the back of the net, while West Ham's goalkeeper made several crucial saves.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, caused the crash by failing to see the motorcyclist as he turned his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family accepted it was a momentary lapse and expressed that nothing could bring Werner back. Werner's defense stated he was remorseful and could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria. He left the UK in January last year and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was active in Syria, posting videos and pictures of his jihad, and was involved in propaganda efforts that appealed to young British Muslims. He was part of a group that produced slick propaganda content, portraying volunteering as a noble and adventurous act. Khawaja was caught attempting to sneak back into the UK, where he faked his death and tried to enter unnoticed. He was arrested at Dover and is now facing a possible prison sentence up to life imprisonment. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, admitted to assisting him. Khawaja has admitted four offenses, and there is an unresolved charge of soliciting to murder. He was held in a high-risk terrorism unit at Belmarsh prison while on remand.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season with Wrexham, helping them finish eighth in the table. He has been signed by Barnsley as their third player for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson for his pace and ability to get past defenders, stating he would fit well into Barnsley's playing style. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for next season.

A container containing bottles of 'Vanish' is believed to have gone overboard from a ship during stormy weather, leading to the bottles washing up on the Cornish coast, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles, as they pose a risk to wildlife. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency noted that while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container with 'Vanish' bottles, there is no current evidence linking the bottles found on the coast to this incident. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact on sensitive marine life, and local authorities are monitoring the beaches. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

A car accident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were implemented via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that investigations into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite for his contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite has joined other players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.

The passage discusses the tension between the Liberal Democrats and Labour Party in the UK Parliament. Lord Oates of the Liberal Democrats accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything," while Baroness Smith of Labour responded that the Liberal Democrats were providing "false hope." The two parties had previously collaborated to oppose the government on issues such as the rights of EU citizens and Brexit, but their cooperation ended when MPs rejected amendments. The Liberal Democrats remained committed to their amendments, while Labour deferred to the Commons. A Labour source in the Lords criticized the Liberal Democrats for "grandstanding" and building false hope, while the Liberal Democrats' Europe spokesperson accused Labour of supporting the government's plans and aligning with the Conservatives. The two parties have a history of collaboration to oppose government bills on various issues, but there are expected to be residual tensions between them.

The passage discusses the low priority of defence in the UK's political agenda, with most parties not prioritizing it despite the increasing global threats. Defence spending has declined, with the UK now ranked sixth in the world, far behind the US, China, and Russia. The UK's military capabilities have been significantly reduced, including the size of its armed forces and the number of warships and aircraft. While some parties, like UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party, support the 2% defence spending target, most do not. The UK is unlikely to meet the NATO 2% target, which could affect its credibility with the US. The political parties are facing pressure to make further cuts to the defence budget, but there is no consensus on how much. The nuclear deterrent, specifically the Trident system, is also under scrutiny, with some parties considering scrapping it. The UK's new aircraft carriers are a symbol of global ambition, but there are concerns about their operational effectiveness due to staffing and equipment issues. Overall, the UK's military is facing challenges in maintaining its global standing due to budget constraints and reduced capabilities.

FC Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club has denied any wrongdoing, stating they paid the correct amount in taxes. However, investigations continue into the transfer due to allegations of higher costs.
