Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash when a Mazda Premacy was driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. The accident occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Luciw, the father of a baby girl, was described as generous, kind-hearted, and a lover of practical jokes. His family expressed sorrow over his loss and emphasized the need for regular driving tests for older drivers. Age UK highlighted the importance of allowing older people to drive for as long as possible. The crash involved Luciw and his colleague Andy Harrington, who managed to swerve but could not avoid the collision. Harrington, who sustained serious injuries, called for medical examinations for retired drivers. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licences, but there are no medical or driving tests. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age, as evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK supports the continued ability of older drivers to maintain independence through safe driving.

Many women have raised concerns about the safety of implants used to treat incontinence after experiencing severe side effects. An independent expert, Alison Britton, will review the final report on the independent review process and its conclusions. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments and given the information to make informed choices. It also emphasized the importance of mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an outright ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The health secretary stated the government does not have the power to ban the procedures, as that is the responsibility of the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite the panel members around the controversial final report. Several members, including women who had suffered complications from the surgery, resigned from the review group, citing dissatisfaction with the report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants in the past 20 years, with over 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke the 25-year-old British 5K record set by Paula McColgan by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken and raised concerns about whether Muir's race met the criteria for record-breaking, including the need for a "genuine race" and potential drug testing. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential, noting her ability to run a 5K in 14.30 and her potential to compete with the world's top athletes. She also mentioned that Muir's race was similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago, where she lapped Paula Radcliffe. Muir has previously broken her own British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou was infected. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, competing 10 months after being in an induced coma. Fox-Pitt led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions the opportunity to meet Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

The passage describes a tennis match between Andy Murray and Fognini. Murray, a British player, won the match 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. He secured a place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Meanwhile, fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week of the tournament with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Maria Sakkari. The match was tense and had a dramatic finish, with Murray overcoming Fognini's challenges and securing the victory. Murray expressed satisfaction with his performance and confidence for the upcoming matches.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people still at the bar, with alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge noted O'Neill's "appalling record" and fined her £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

The passage discusses Mike Nesbitt's speech launching the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, where he emphasized the importance of partnership over domination. Nesbitt's remarks, particularly his comment about wanting to go into Stormont with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin, have drawn attention. The speech also highlights the party's focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and their manifesto, 'Real Partnership', which includes calls for action on various issues. Nesbitt defended his comments and expressed confidence in his position and the party's strategy. The election is framed as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive and the overall performance of the current government.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales in implementing 'Turing's Law'. This law will provide posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences and allow living men to apply for pardons. The motion is expected to include the same provisions, ensuring equal treatment for gay and bisexual men as their counterparts in England and Wales. The minister stated that arrangements will be implemented as soon as possible to rectify past injustices.

Yvonne Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in the 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking the previous Scottish record set by Yvonne Murray in 1994 and moving her to second on the British all-time list. Muir, who previously finished fifth in the World Championships, now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She expressed excitement about her performance and her first race of the season at this distance. Muir is aiming to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham. She started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and is set to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir, who is pursuing her fourth year of veterinary studies, has been training intensively.
The passage provides a collection of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality.

Richard Horwell QC, a Met Police barrister, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive for killing Alexander Litvinenko. He suggested the Russian state was likely involved in the plot, citing the use of polonium-210, a radioactive substance, which indicates state participation. Litvinenko was poisoned in 2006 during a meeting with the suspects and died three weeks later. Horwell emphasized that while the Russian state may have been involved, it does not confirm direct involvement of Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticism of Putin were potential motives. Horwell also mentioned that the suspects left a trail of polonium and had no credible explanation for the scientific evidence. The inquiry into the case was adjourned, and attempts to extradite the suspects to the UK have failed, with Kovtun criticized for not giving evidence.

Australia's Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the captain of the one-day side and will also lead the Twenty20 team in the absence of injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith is praised for his talent and leadership abilities, with national selector Rod Marsh highlighting his potential as a suitable successor to Michael Clarke, who has retired after Australia's Ashes defeat. Smith has played in 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner, despite a history of disciplinary issues, has matured into an important senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting on 20 August.

The passage discusses a political figure's stance on LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage. He expressed support for LGBT-plus rights and stated that defending equal marriage would be a priority. He refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that he believed everyone was a sinner. He also mentioned wanting to extend marital rights to transgender people, highlighting the issue of the spousal veto. He explained his vote against the 2007 Equality Bill, citing concerns about individual liberties, but did not specify those concerns directly. He emphasized his support for equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, UK, in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare is now using the plant for pharmaceutical production, with the hope that many jobs will be filled by former Sanofi employees. The company believes the investment will have a "very positive" impact on the area. Newcastle City Council's leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, praised the announcement, highlighting Accord's role as a global player in the pharmaceutical industry and the benefits for the local economy through skilled jobs and long-term investment. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the local authority at the end of their contracts, with Monaghan and Sutherland departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, criticized the council's inability to retain senior staff, anticipating further departures. Ellis was the interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office and Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

Martin Martin, an English rider, crashed at this year's TT and has faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his departure from road racing but later clarified that he is not giving up on racing, specifically stating he has no plans to compete in road racing on Hondas this year. Martin did not race at the North West 200 following his teammate's crash and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and mentioned that after testing at Cadwell, he decided the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. Martin expressed a desire to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated as president on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline was reinforced by election results, particularly in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and in Adamawa, which was heavily affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The PDP's failure to gain national support, with success limited to the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta, has relegated it to a regional party. The APC's victory in Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, marks the first time the president's party has controlled the state since multi-party democracy began in 1999. The PDP is expected to undergo introspection and rebuilding under a new leader. The PDP faced criticism for corruption and failure to combat the Islamist insurgency in the north-east. The elections were marred by violence, particularly in southern states, but were generally more peaceful than previous years, indicating progress in Nigeria's democracy.

The passage discusses allegations by the US-based environmental group Mighty against Olam, an agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. The allegations claim that Olam and Temasek are turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices, which may contribute to the annual haze in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia. The haze is primarily caused by slash-and-burn practices by small-scale farmers and rogue palm oil traders in Indonesia. Olam denies the allegations, stating it has a strict sourcing policy that prohibits burning, peat use, and deforestation. It also claims it buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and is a relative newcomer to the industry. The report suggests that Olam's sourcing practices may be encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading, which could be linked to the haze. Temasek has also denied the allegations, stating it supports no-burn policies and does not direct the operations of its portfolio companies. The passage also highlights the global issues within the palm oil industry, including deforestation, burning, and labor practices, and mentions concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started serving puppy platters following the introduction of a new law that permits dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only played from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent may return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield due to a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late goal against the Terriers from the bench.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator stated that the ban on YouTube was no longer necessary as Google had launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. YouTube has denied claims that authorities can filter content, and many young Pakistanis have welcomed the lifting of the ban. However, some activists have called for greater transparency in the agreement between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that all internet service providers had been directed to open access to YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd posted on its Facebook page welcoming back YouTube. The Pakistan ministry of information technology stated that Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offending material, which Google would then restrict. A YouTube spokeswoman said government requests for content removal would not automatically be granted and that content would be reviewed before restrictions. The ban on YouTube was imposed by Pakistan's Supreme Court in 2012 after the film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded, which led to widespread protests and deaths. Google recently launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian and shares nationality with one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala previously stepped aside from the 2015 elections due to this conflict of interest. Musa Bility of the Liberian FA threatens to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter is in 18 days. Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations states that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee with a conflict of interest must be replaced. In the 2015 election, Scala and Claudio Sulser stepped aside to avoid any appearance of conflict. Andreas Bantel, Scala's spokesman, argues that having the same nationality as a candidate does not create a conflict of interest. Bility, who was denied eligibility to run, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali. The election will take place in Zurich with five candidates: Prince Ali of Jordan, Gianni Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman of Bahrain, and Tokyo Sexwale of South Africa.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road after a flashover explosion, which is believed to have been caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, leading to a fire-ball effect. The men were working in a paint-spraying area when the incident occurred shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been conducted at the company, and significant progress has been made in the investigation, with witness statements and evidence being gathered. The Health and Safety Executive is also involved in collecting evidence.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints it lodged against the organization during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was allowed to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. Morocco was previously banned for not staging the 2015 Nations Cup due to concerns over the Ebola virus, and they were later fined $50,000 after Cas reduced the fine. Equatorial Guinea took over as the 2015 hosts. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament was in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal resolved the issue. Tunisia is set to face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia reaches the 2017 finals, they will achieve their thirteenth consecutive participation in the Nations Cup, a record.

In the 95th minute of a 3-1 victory at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred, resulting in Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off. Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's role in the incident. Aguero, 28, received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on David Luiz. Fernandinho, who clashed with Fabregas during the scuffle, will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot plan in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd aimed at improving early cancer diagnosis. It highlights the challenges of diagnosing cancer in people without clear symptoms, as well as the current low diagnosis rate in the area. The plan involves referring patients to diagnostic services in Denmark and the establishment of a new diagnostic clinic in Port Talbot. The goal is to streamline the diagnostic process, reduce the time taken for diagnosis, and improve outcomes for patients. Experts believe the plan could significantly impact the diagnosis of cancer in the region.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the first Test at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, marking their second-largest win in runs against Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Root's disciplined and controlled innings was praised by captain Alastair Cook, who highlighted his exceptional performance. The match was played on a pitch that offered little assistance to the bowlers, and Pakistan's batting showed signs of decline, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50 in the series. Despite the loss, Pakistan's players expressed hope for improvement in the upcoming matches.

The British and Irish Lions are led by head coach Warren Gatland, with interim coach Rob Howley in his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed excitement about the opportunity to lead the team. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is planning to appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour and is in advanced discussions with other individuals to confirm the full management team. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips and union chairman Gareth Davies believe the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide valuable experience for Welsh rugby in the future.

Hull City secured a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending their six-game losing streak and their first league win since August 20. The match was marked by Hull's early loss of key strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, but Robert Snodgrass' return from injury helped turn the game in Hull's favor. Snodgrass scored his fourth league goal of the season and assisted Michael Dawson's goal, which came from a free-kick. Southampton, who had a strong European game against Inter Milan, struggled to maintain their rhythm and were unable to equalize despite efforts from David Marshall, who made several crucial saves. The win was a significant boost for Hull, who remain in the bottom three heading into the international break. The match ended with Hull's second goal coming from a corner in added time, with Sam Clucas making a remarkable goalline clearance.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at about 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist, who lived locally, has not been further identified. The tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, with opposition leader Zoran Zaev calling it illegal and urging protesters to gather in Skopje. The crisis was sparked by recordings from 2015, which allege ministers were plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. These recordings, released by Zaev, claim to show widespread corruption, including the misuse of funds and dubious criminal prosecutions. The government denies these accusations, accusing Zaev of trying to destabilize the country. The EU has warned that Ivanov's actions could jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership ambitions.

Swansea City will be managed by Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams in their upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club aims to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes the team needs a manager who will help them avoid relegation, acknowledging the difficulty of recovering from relegation. Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and almost being relegated in 2003. Curtis feels the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, noting the change in management has diluted the "Swansea Way." However, he believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new signings of the club's history and importance to the area.

The passage discusses a football match between Dagenham & Redbridge and Leyton Orient. Dagenham, who reached League One in 2010, needed a win to keep their slim survival hopes alive. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave them hope, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner, leading to Dagenham's relegation and keeping Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached the Football League for the first time in 2007, are now returning to the National League under manager John Still. Dagenham has struggled with a poor goal difference and an ineffective attack, with Jamie Cureton scoring nine goals this season compared to 20 in the previous campaign. Still is committed to helping Dagenham gain promotion next season. Leyton Orient, who lost two managers this season, are now two points adrift of the play-off spots. Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games to reach the play-offs. Dagenham's manager, Still, acknowledged the team's lack of organization and discipline as factors in their defeat.

The former Liverpool captain, Steven Gerrard, will return to his former club, Liverpool, as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp praised the appointment, calling it "wonderful news" and expressing confidence in Gerrard's future as a manager. Gerrard, who played for Liverpool from 1998 to 2015, retired in November after a 19-year career. He had previously been linked with a managerial role at MK Dons but declined it, stating it was "too soon." Gerrard is also working towards obtaining a Uefa A coaching licence, which is necessary to manage in the Premier League.
McManus opened the scoring early, followed by Ross Forbes' goal. McAusland's goal brought Alloa back into the game, but McManus and Denny Johnstone's late goals secured a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in poor conditions in three closed schools in Birmingham, with owners facing up to 51 weeks in jail. Ministers are consulting on stricter regulations for schools operating more than 6-8 hours weekly. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern over the conditions and the risk of abuse or radicalization. Over 18 unregulated schools, mostly in Muslim communities, have been investigated, with three in Birmingham closed. Some schools use legal terms like "part-time education centres" to operate illegally. The government is funding a team of inspectors to tackle illegal schools, with regulations applying to all religious groups. The education secretary plans to prosecute unregistered schools and has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution. A consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and aims to capture the local flavour palette and terroir of the Teviot valley. The distillery is part of efforts to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837, with proposals at various stages of the planning process. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlighted the potential to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence," emphasizing the small scale of their operation. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting the area's landscape and the strength of the female production team. The distillery is positioned as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery, aligning with the ethos of local sourcing.

Harry Whitlam died when Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013. Green was more than twice the legal drinking limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. Leeds Crown Court heard Green was on private land at the time of the incident, leading to his prosecution under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks and had previously admitted failing to ensure the safety of others. The incident occurred when Green was walking towards a worker in a closed-off area of the farm and backed the tractor into Harry. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's behavior as "reckless." Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact of the tragedy on her family, emphasizing the importance of not allowing drunk driving, whether on public or private land.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and participate in friendly matches with new club Barcelona after his appeal against a four-month suspension for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. He will join Barcelona's first team training session and has a public presentation scheduled for Monday at Camp Nou. While he cannot play in Monday's game against Club Leon, he is now available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. Suarez's lawyers argued that the FIFA suspension was too harsh, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) confirmed the sanctions but deemed them excessive. Suarez will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games and is expected to make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez has previously been suspended for biting and racially abusing players.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who was carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-metre course with hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event allowed all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. Richard mentioned they trained for a week and were pushed hard by the Lithuanians. They will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond addressed concerns about job losses at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) following the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October 2014. He assured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that while job roles may change due to the introduction of an electronic system allowing monthly direct debits, any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Hammond noted that changes in job roles may require training on new processes, but he emphasized the government's commitment to supporting DVLA employees. Mike Hedges welcomed the assurances, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing disappointment over the potential reduction in job opportunities.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on EU interference in domestic matters, with Minister Szijjarto asserting that the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" such as asylum controls, NGO regulations, and a higher education law. Hungary has received backing from Poland to veto any EU action against it. The EU is critical of Hungary's policies, particularly the higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University (CEU), and the NGO law, which could stigmatize NGOs as "foreign-backed." Hungary is under pressure from European institutions to withdraw these laws, with the EU considering sanctions. The country is also housing asylum seekers in shipping containers, raising concerns about compliance with EU law.

The passage discusses the casting and release details of a film. The star will play Mrs Potts, a teapot housekeeper voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, the father of Belle. The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson is cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad will play LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and writer, passed away after being diagnosed with multiple cancers. He was known for his bold and often controversial writing style, which earned him both admiration and criticism. Gill was a long-time contributor to the Sunday Times, where he was described as the "heart and soul" of the paper. He was also recognized for his wit, intelligence, and compassion. Gill's career began in the 1980s with art reviews and continued with writing for Tatler and the Sunday Times. He was married twice, first to Cressida Connolly and later to Amber Rudd. Gill's illness led to his engagement to his partner, Nicola Formby, with whom he had two children. His final column, discussing his diagnosis, was published in the Sunday Times. His death was met with widespread tribute from colleagues and former editors, who remembered him as a giant among journalists.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was attacked in Ulan Bator. According to Russian news reports, he was hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy investigated the incident but called local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar wore a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol that predates the Nazi era. His father reported that Sukhbaatar was seriously injured, spending about 10 days in a coma. Sukhbaatar emphasized the swastika's traditional significance in Mongolia. The Russian embassy denied the attack occurred as reported, stating the details were "distorted." The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not arrested due to the injury not being serious, according to a police spokesman. The musician's lawyer, father, and band member denied reports that Sukhbaatar shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show.

Plane Stupid campaigners demonstrated against the airport's expansion plans on Monday, facing charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on 19 August and the protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The Metropolitan Police have stated they will review security at the airport.

Glamorgan's total was dominated by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, but seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured wickets fell regularly. Gloucestershire struggled as the bowlers remained on top. Selman's return to form followed a string of low scores, and Aneurin Donald scored 36 off 30 balls. Glamorgan's captain is Michael Hogan, with Jacques Rudolph absent due to a neck injury. Gloucestershire's innings was a survival effort, ending evenly balanced. Both teams had mixed performances, with Glamorgan securing a bonus point. Selman and Taylor expressed satisfaction with their performances, while Gloucestershire's seamer Matt Taylor highlighted the challenge ahead for the batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after contacting the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes planned to make a false report to the police, leading to an ambush, while intoxicated, to shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made twice, late at night. Judge Niclas Parry noted Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. His legal team stated he did not intend to kill himself or threaten police officers. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling.

Yorkshire were defeated by Surrey in a white-ball match, with Surrey posting a score of 255-7, including a stand of 130 between Davies and Ben Foakes. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who took 3-61, including victims Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan scored 68 but was the last to fall as Yorkshire were all out for 236. Despite a strong start, Yorkshire struggled in the final overs, with Bresnan holed out at long-off with seven balls remaining. Surrey's captain Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes' partnership, while Yorkshire's captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, acknowledging the team's struggles in crucial moments.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST after water began entering the boat. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump on board and towed the vessel to Holyhead due to the pump's inability to handle the incoming water.

Muir has announced she will not be part of the Scotland team at next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir is pursuing her degree, which is important to her, and will return to university soon. She is disappointed to miss the Commonwealth Games but is optimistic about her future in athletics, potentially targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir also expressed satisfaction with her performance at the World Championships, where she set a new outdoor personal best.

Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool's struggles in the Premier League, noting that they are far from repeating last season's title challenge. He highlights issues with their attacking options, particularly the loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, and the lack of effective strikers in their current lineup. Savage also points out defensive problems, including the lack of a leader in the back and the poor performance of their goalkeeper, Simon Mignolet. He predicts that Liverpool will struggle against Chelsea, who are in better form and have a stronger team. Savage also discusses Steven Gerrard's future with Liverpool, acknowledging his challenges but believing he can still play a key role in the team's long-term future.

A £45m facility is to be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was a passionate advocate for education and transitioned from teaching to writing in 1975. He is known for his contributions to literature, including the Laidlaw trilogy and the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He also contributed to journalism, broadcasting, and political and sporting life in Scotland. McIlvanney passed away on 5 December.

The passage describes an evacuation near a swimming pool in a town due to a sea mine discovered near the river. The mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, required careful handling. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea, with residents advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. The mine was moved to a safer location before being dealt with, as its condition was uncertain. The evacuation affected three streets and residents within 500 meters of the device. Ferry services were also disrupted. Authorities emphasized that the evacuation was precautionary and there was no immediate danger to the community.

The passage discusses the funding decisions for various sports in preparation for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have missed out on funding, while cycling has seen its funding reduced by over £4 million. A total of £345 million will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is £2 million less than the £347 million allocated for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set a target for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which had a bronze medal in Rio, is the only sport that lost its funding, with its chief executive expressing concern over the decision. Judo, which also won a bronze in Rio, has seen a slight increase in funding. UK Sport's CEO, Liz Nicholl, stated that funding decisions are made to prioritize and enhance medal potential. The review process aimed to build performance pathways for future success, but some sports, such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, have had their funding withdrawn in the past. UK Sport has yet to confirm funding for the five new Olympic sports and two new Paralympic sports. Baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, and surfing will return to the program, as will Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton. Funding will be determined based on medal potential, with £9 million of the £345 million still to be allocated.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks are set to replace three Victorian hotels at East Cliff in Bournemouth. English Heritage opposed the development, citing its impact on the designated conservation area. Councillors voted seven to three in favor, arguing the project would boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. The site will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. The project, led by East Cliff Project LLP, will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. While 246 letters supported the plans, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, emphasizing the historic character of the area.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely, 24, during a night out in Brecon. The jury cleared Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Boyd, who served with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was found unconscious in the early hours of 8 May after being punched and beaten outside a bar. CCTV footage showed the attack, with Vallely dragging Boyd's body from the scene. The killer was described as being on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon." A family tribute highlighted Boyd's positive traits and the community's outpouring of support, while also expressing the profound impact of his death on the family.

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an error that caused issues with voter registration. Initially, 155 polling stations were inaccessible as voters' names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and a council spokesperson praised Travers for his contributions during his three and a half years in the role. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer-term arrangements are determined. On election day, some polling stations had only a few voters on the register, leading to concerns about the fairness of the election. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issues, and a review will conclude by the end of May, examining the arrangements for the EU Referendum. The council is currently discussing who will lead the investigation.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where both teams showcased impressive set-piece play. Josh Gillies scored a fine free-kick for Gateshead, putting them ahead. Wrexham equalized through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman secured the victory with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half improvement, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with their second-half performance. The match ended with Gateshead winning 2-1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway ranking first and Afghanistan, followed by Mozambique, ranking the lowest.

The passage discusses the OneWeb project, which aims to create a global broadband network using a large constellation of satellites. Initially, the network will consist of at least 600 spacecraft, with the potential to expand to over 2,000. The goal is to provide broadband connections to every school globally. To achieve this, Airbus and OneWeb are implementing new, high-volume, low-cost satellite manufacturing methods, similar to car and plane factories, with plans to produce three units per shift at under a million dollars each. The project involves establishing assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and Florida, with the first satellites scheduled for launch in April 2021 and another batch in November. The constellation will require a significant rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles planned to launch the satellites. OneWeb also faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing, but believes it has a first-mover advantage. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional funding. OneWeb is based in the UK but must comply with UK Space Agency regulations. The project also focuses on debris mitigation, with a commitment to de-orbiting satellites within two years and using additional hardware to ensure safe re-entry. The passage highlights the potential impact of these new manufacturing approaches on the satellite industry.

The passage discusses the disagreement between the UK government and the Scottish government regarding public spending. Mr. Swinney, the Scottish government's chief secretary, stated that the UK government's recent spending review placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. The UK government claims that Scottish ministers will have £390m more in spending available to them next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010, along with the recent spending review, mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr. Swinney emphasized that the UK government has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year from now until 2020, with more than £1bn of those cuts still to come. He also stated that Scotland will defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. The UK government's Scotland Office responded by stating that the Scottish government will have £390m more spending available next year, and that the block grant will be almost £30bn. Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, criticized Mr. Swinney's comments and called for a long-term budget that offers a real alternative to austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities in finding accessible toilet facilities, particularly in public spaces. It highlights the need for "Changing Places" toilets, which are larger and equipped with additional features to accommodate people who require two carers or a hoist to change. While there are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, they are not yet compulsory in building regulations. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers, are advocating for these toilets to be made mandatory in larger buildings such as shopping centres, cinemas, and stadiums. The passage also mentions the positive impact of Changing Places toilets, as seen at Arsenal Football Club, and the psychological effects of not having access to these facilities on families. Despite some logistical and financial barriers, there is a growing push to make Changing Places toilets a standard requirement in new building projects.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has formally complained to the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. McDonald's defended its approach, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and other European unions support the complaint, arguing that McDonald's abuse of its market position harms franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and may investigate if the allegations are valid. The consumer organisations claim that franchisees are restricted from switching to competitors due to long contracts and that premises are leased at above-market rates, leading to higher prices and reduced consumer choice. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and the company generated $9.27bn in revenue from franchised restaurants globally in 2014.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, has gone viral, leading to the appearance of a poster with the hashtag #prayforjosh in Holywood. The campaign, started by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father is a pastoral staff member, has received widespread global support. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressed surprise at the level of support and mentioned that a mystery donor paid for a massive billboard in Holywood. The hashtag has been shared over 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people, with significant support also coming from Twitter. The campaign has brought international attention to Josh and his family as they continue to support his recovery.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales as part of a military reorganisation. Chris Davies, a Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP, condemned the decision, highlighting the barracks' long history since 1805 and its role in military conflicts. He expressed concern over the impact on the local economy and military tourism, and plans to launch a petition against the closure. The Defence Secretary, Sir Michael Fallon, announced the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and the closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the potential negative effects on local livelihoods.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that the UK may need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal. Fishing regions around the UK supported leaving the EU during the referendum. The Lords review warns that these communities could be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is seen as detrimental to the UK fishing industry, which helped drive the leave vote. However, Brexit could offer the industry the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, similar to Norway. The House of Lords European Union Committee report notes that the fishing industry is a low priority for the government but must not be marginalized. The UK's fishing industry is complex due to shared fish stocks with EU coastal states and reliance on EU markets. The report suggests that the CFP should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should continue to cooperate with neighboring states. There is a risk of four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if the CFP framework falls away. Despite concerns, the fishing industry remains optimistic about Brexit bringing opportunities for fairer shares and sustainable management. The UK government emphasizes the need to ensure British companies have maximum trade freedom while reviewing fisheries management.

Ed Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of the leaks in an interview with the Guardian. He leaked documents revealing the US National Security Agency (NSA) has extensive access to individual data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The NSA has also used Prism, which provides backdoor access to servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple, allowing the collection of private data. While the US government claims these operations help keep Americans secure, experts question their true extent. The NSA and other agencies argue that surveillance is necessary for national security, but critics, including privacy advocates, express concerns about privacy and the potential for abuse. The US Patriot Act and cloud computing practices further complicate data protection, as user data is often stored outside the user's country, making it easier for foreign governments to access. The EU and other governments have expressed concerns about the implications of Prism for citizens' privacy. Snowden's leaks have sparked global discussions about privacy, surveillance, and the balance between national security and individual rights.

OpenAI is a venture backed by Tesla Motors, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, Paypal co-founder Peter Thiel, Indian tech giant Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The organization aims to focus on AI research that is free from financial obligations and is expected to have a positive human impact. While some experts warn that AI advancements could pose a threat to humanity, others argue the risk is remote. OpenAI's statement emphasizes that AI should be an extension of human will and as broadly and evenly distributed as possible safely, with only a small fraction of the $1bn pledged being spent in the next few years.

Ben Parkinson, a former soldier, was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Since carrying the Olympic torch on June 26, he has received thousands of Facebook requests, but is limited to 5,000 friend associations. Flanked by hundreds of people, he walked with the torch for nearly half an hour, supported by an assistant. Despite a brain injury that affected his speech, his personality and sense of humor remain unchanged. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and uses crutches. He raises money for military charities and is a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother said the support has been phenomenal, with thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website and many messages of support. Facebook advised him to consider a page or use a subscription for public updates. A total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame on an 8,000-mile, 70-day journey to the London Olympics opening ceremony on July 27.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with the rate remaining stable after three years of increases. The real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the US reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new contract with the club until 2019. He is a specialist in short-format cricket and has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and his contribution to the team's success, including his role in winning the T20 Blast final. Buttler, currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register interest in the ships, with viewings planned for late February and March. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted, and a final decision is expected in the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the country's industry capacity. Penny Mordaunt, a Conservative MP, supports saving at least one frigate from scrap, suggesting it could be a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence considers all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. The Type 22 frigates were designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into versatile combatants with advanced capabilities. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for £3 million as scrap.

Fiji has experienced significant instability and international isolation since 1987 due to racial and political tensions. A 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated government, leading to the introduction and withdrawal of a constitution that enshrined indigenous Fijian political supremacy. A 2000 coup led by George Speight resulted in the hostage-taking of the prime minister and his cabinet, causing economic harm and damaging Fiji's international reputation. Tensions over the 2000 coup led to a bloodless military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth over its lack of progress towards democracy. In 2012, the government agreed to free elections, which led to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and the reinstallation of Fiji in the Commonwealth. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter fleeing in the mid-2000s, leading to indigenous Fijians forming a majority. The economy relies on sugar and tourism, but is also diverse with mining, services, and manufacturing. However, Fiji faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Syria is working to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia, with the second shipment intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims rebels have taken control of the prison. The government has faced criticism from the US for its use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, with reports of civilian casualties. The UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons is falling behind schedule, with only 4% of the stockpile having left the country. Russia, a key ally of Syria, has urged Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by March. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons has acknowledged that the process has been slowed down by security concerns. The Syrian government has stated its commitment to fulfilling its obligations under the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The Lives of Others by Mukherjee is the favorite to win the Booker Prize, with bookmakers William Hill giving it 5/2 odds. The prize is now open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. The shortlisted authors are Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the best-selling novel on the list, having sold over 55,000 copies since its publication. The Booker Prize is now in its 46th year, and the judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton from New Zealand.

The passage discusses a legal case involving a man (referred to as PJS) who is appealing against a ruling by an appeal court that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments about whether it should allow or dismiss the appeal. An interim injunction remains in place until the conclusion of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wishes to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues for his right to privacy and has taken legal action. The Court of Appeal ruled that there must be no publication leading to the disclosure of PJS's identity before a specific time on Wednesday. The High Court initially refused to impose an injunction, but the appeal court ruled in PJS's favor, preventing his identification in publications. The Sun's publishers then sought to lift the ban, arguing that the story had been published elsewhere, but the Court of Appeal judges ruled that the ban should remain due to the widespread nature of the allegations.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased for £345.5m. The new owners are planning improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the park's units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have met with the council to address potential planning issues. He noted that Fosse Park is a key entry point to the city and sees it as an investment for improvement. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to address parking, congestion, and the quality of common areas, as the park has become tired over the years.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia after it was reported to include a "gay moment," leading to its delayed release. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit regarding the gay moment, despite homosexuality being illegal in Malaysia. The film was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification." While the LPF approved the film, the release date and screening locations remain under the jurisdiction of local cinema chains. The film's director, Bill Condon, described the "gay moment" as an exclusive side-plot involving LeFou. The decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens, who called it "stupid and laughable."

Landlords in Southampton who let properties to more than three unrelated tenants must apply for a licence for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO), which can cost £1,000. Failure to do so can result in fines of up to £20,000. The council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Many landlords are deterred by the cost, despite the risks. Nationally, HMO licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licensing applies to specific areas. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance. Concerns about eviction and poor housing conditions are common among HMO tenants.

The passage discusses the efforts by Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil to avoid a second election. Micheál Martin has indicated his party will support a minority government but will not back a programme for government. A key issue is the water charges, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their role. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. No party could form a majority government, and TDs have not yet elected a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was en route to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of its car decks, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire quickly became uncontrollable, leading to the evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. The passengers were rescued by the ferry Puglia and are on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people have been injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt. Spanish officials mentioned that psychologists would be sent to the port for counselling. The port authority warned that the Sorrento might sink due to the fire. The ferry sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time, and the captain initially did not believe an evacuation was necessary, but the fire's intensity led to a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs highlighted concerns about individuals, including students, who claimed to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. The Commission emphasized the need for better integration of individual electoral registers to identify duplicate entries. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% voting, the highest turnout since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications following the snap poll and the deadline. However, concerns over duplicate applications persist, with estimates ranging between 30% and 70% in different areas. The lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service contributes to the problem. The watchdog called for clearer information and verification functions on registration sites. Despite efforts to prevent duplicates, the issue remains, and the Commission urged urgent action. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, noting that some people may lawfully be registered in multiple constituencies.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, is believed to have killed himself early on Wednesday. He was a star player at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and a sought-after rookie in the NFL, playing for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999. Phillips faced numerous issues both on and off the field during his career. After retiring, he continued to have legal problems, including convictions for assault. He was sent to prison for over 30 years after being convicted of assault for driving into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. Phillips was placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate. On Tuesday, a judge found enough evidence to try Phillips in the death of Damion Soward, 37. Phillips' death is unclear, but his former coach, Tom Osborne, noted that he was an intelligent and kind person with anger issues and unresolved personal struggles.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a mascot ram of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal in Chester, marked by Brigadier Andrew Williams. He is the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the mid-19th century. Private Derby XXX, officially classified as a soldier, joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, receives payment for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage describes a dramatic 4-3 victory by Liverpool over Borussia Dortmund in a Champions League match, which is considered one of the most exciting games at Anfield. The match was marked by intense emotions, a passionate atmosphere, and a significant turnaround for Liverpool, who were behind early but managed to secure a win. The victory was inspired by Klopp's leadership and the team's resilience, echoing the 2005 Champions League final win. Klopp's approach emphasized belief and determination, which were evident in the players' performance. The game also highlighted the growing identity of Liverpool under Klopp, with key players like Divock Origi and Philippe Coutinho contributing to the victory. The match had a special significance, with a memorable atmosphere and emotional moments, including a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster. The win brought Liverpool closer to the Champions League, and Klopp expressed confidence in the team's ability to achieve more.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government officials expressed views on the negotiations with the EU. Mr. Davis emphasized the importance of keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about the negotiations and proposed monthly meetings to ensure a "two-way information flow" with the devolved administrations. He stated that the meeting was constructive and aimed at working together to achieve the best deal for the UK. Mr. Russell highlighted the need for greater transparency and clarity from the UK government, particularly regarding Scotland's position on EU market access and whether the UK intends to remain in the single market or customs union. The UK government hopes the High Court judgment on Article 50 will be overturned in the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the appeal.

The passage discusses a study on cloned sheep, specifically focusing on the health and aging of the clones. Dr. Sandra Corr examines Daisy, one of four cloned sheep (along with Debbie, Denise, and Diane) created from the same adult ewe as Dolly the first cloned mammal. These sheep are part of a flock of 13 living on a university farm. The study, led by Prof. Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and if they are healthier than non-cloned animals. The research involves thorough physical examinations, including joint checks, X-rays, and MRI scans, to assess conditions like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The study's results could have significant implications for the future of cloning. Despite Dolly's premature death at six-and-a-half years old due to illness, the cloned sheep appear to be in good health as they approach their ninth and tenth birthdays.

John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won the race by a length and three quarters after walking the course. She is set to race at Chantilly rather than the Oaks at Epsom, where Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed's victory marks a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Dettori praised Shutter Speed's performance, noting the soft ground and her potential on better conditions. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will walk the course again before deciding whether to run him in the Derby trial. Shutter Speed will race in the Oaks at Chantilly, a distance suited to her, while the gap between the Dante Stakes and the Derby is just 16 days, which may affect Cracksman's chances in the Dante.

The passage discusses the fluctuations in the pound against major currencies and the impact of the Brexit referendum on financial markets. Initially, the pound fell against the dollar and euro but recovered before falling again. The volatility index reached crisis levels, indicating heightened uncertainty. The Leave campaign argued the pound had retreated to March levels, with the pound down 0.2% against the dollar and 0.6% against the euro. Concerns over a Remain vote and global economic worries contributed to market volatility. Polls suggested a closer race between the Leave and Remain campaigns, leading to increased uncertainty and further volatility in the pound. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group being the biggest faller. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage noted that the pound had strengthened since March, and a weaker pound is beneficial for UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They faced a tough challenge against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Despite conceding a goal early in the match, Braintree's manager Cowley remained positive, acknowledging the team's remarkable performance so far and expressing confidence in facing their toughest challenge yet.

The passage discusses a proposed change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will gain more responsibility for planning decisions, including accepting or rejecting developments in their areas. Currently, planning decisions are made by the Planning Service, an agency under Stormont's environment department. The shift aims to democratize the planning process, with elected politicians making decisions. Michael Corr, a creative director, supports the move, seeing it as an opportunity for local councils to develop their communities. However, concerns are raised about the skills of politicians in urban planning and the potential for discrimination or unfair treatment of communities. Environmental groups warn of the need for strict codes of conduct to ensure fairness and transparency. They also highlight the importance of transparency in political donations to prevent conflicts of interest. Some local politicians are opposed to the change due to concerns about donor safety and the relevance of donation disclosure limits in Northern Ireland.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, including twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which required amputation. The cat is described as "incredibly lucky" to survive. The incident occurred in a housing estate with many children, raising concerns about the potential for crossfire. The Scottish SPCA and the cat's owner are urging the Scottish government to implement air weapon licensing to prevent such incidents. Last year, a consultation on air weapon licensing was held, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan, with 87% rejecting the idea. The Scottish SPCA is urging the public to come forward with any information related to the incident.

Liverpool has signed Belgium international Sylvain Benteke on a long-term contract, making him the club's second most expensive signing. Benteke, who previously played for Aston Villa, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. The signing comes after Liverpool sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. The club aims to revive their attacking options following the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Benteke is expected to contribute to Liverpool's forward line, with other signings including Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge are optimistic about Benteke's potential at Anfield.

The passage discusses a study on the use of tablet devices in schools, highlighting that there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils. The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, examined 671 state and independent schools and found that many pupils use tablets at home for social media. Tablets are increasingly used in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them. However, the study found no definitive link between tablet use and improved academic results. Despite this, some educators report positive impacts, such as increased motivation and family involvement. The use of tablets is expected to grow, with the number of tablets in schools rising from 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. Tablets are becoming a significant part of everyday life for young people, with some pupils described as internet "addicts." Schools are adopting tablets to stay current with technology and to reflect real-world usage.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning over 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing the lives of children in Liverpool. The images provide a social history of the city and highlight changes in childhood over time, including special occasions and the role of children in work. The oldest photograph is from 1887, showing the Rollo family at a fancy dress ball, while another image from around 1900 depicts a young maid. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Anderson, 27, has mutually agreed to cancel his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Anderson may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, is set to join the Gulls after being recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has had spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move is subject to international clearance. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership and potential, while acknowledging Keating's youth and hunger to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone but have only won one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law was approved by Congress and signed into effect by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales. The legislation aims to address Bolivia's needs as one of the poorest countries in South America and includes harsher penalties for violence against children, such as a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work to support their families, often in difficult conditions. The law reflects a balance between international conventions and Bolivia's realities, with the government hoping it will help reduce extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation is reviewing the law to determine if it complies with international regulations on child labor.

A 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, experienced a heart attack after falling ill at home and researching her symptoms online. She searched for "women's heart attack symptoms," which included sudden nausea and aches, and took aspirin. She visited a cardiologist, who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. O'Donnell described her symptoms as worsening after helping a woman in her village home. In a blog post, she referred to her attack as the "widow maker" and warned women to recognize symptoms and call 911. O'Donnell has acted in several films and TV shows but recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy, identified as Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow, was stabbed during a fight at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. He was stabbed in an alleyway around 00:30 GMT and was pronounced dead about an hour later. Another 16-year-old was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital. Police believe Che was not involved in an early altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man, two boys aged 15 and 16, and a 14-year-old boy have been arrested on suspicion of murder and possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a new approach to cancer diagnosis in Denmark, which has been adopted by Wales. The system aims to improve the diagnosis of cancer cases that are not initially obvious. The model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centres for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have led to better organisation of patient diagnosis and improved survival rates. The system has been successful in Denmark, and there is potential for Wales to learn from Denmark's approach to improve its own cancer diagnosis processes.

The UK government has decided to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), and Powys has been selected to take over its responsibilities. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders if necessary. However, they will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this will show Powys can take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers organization has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce to address staffing shortages and improve patient care. A Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses and pharmacists filling in for doctors and GPs, highlighting the need for more training and support.
