While the plan aims to help cover for doctor shortages and adapt to the changing nature of care, unions warn against using it as a quick fix for chronic staffing issues. The report emphasizes the importance of training and funding for the workforce, with concerns raised about the long-term training of doctors and the lack of funding for training courses. NHS Employers aims to implement the report's recommendations, while unions stress the need for proper training and support for doctors and other health workers.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First stated that while some services had resumed, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed gratitude for public support and staff efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) and the Natural Resources Wales (NRW) regarding the environmental impact of a tidal lagoon project in Swansea. NRW estimates that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout would die annually due to the lagoon's effects on fish migration. TLP disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and that NRW did not share its methodology. TLP's computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species being killed. The £1.3bn project is seen as a test for larger versions along the Welsh coast. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and the Welsh Government supports the scheme but seeks clarity on the UK's position. NRW rejects TLP's criticism, stating they have thoroughly reviewed evidence and data.

Northern Ireland's agri-food industry, which supports almost 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution, will have a new industry-led marketing body established by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The move was announced by DETI Minister Arlene Foster, who highlighted the importance of the sector and the opportunity for collaboration between government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supported the announcement, noting the need for better coordination of marketing activities but also mentioned potential implications for other organizations, including her own department.

A public planting event is taking place at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, organized by the Woodland Trust. The event aims to plant thousands of native UK trees as a tribute to the millions of people who died during WW1. The four-year project is one of the trust's most ambitious planting programmes and involves planting 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood to commemorate the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The trust is inviting the public to participate in the planting and is providing saplings for volunteers. The project aims to create a place where wildlife will thrive and where people can walk, relax, and reflect. The trees will stand for generations as a living tribute to those who served in the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honour crime. The award was presented at the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate. Alison Graham, a Radio Times TV editor and judge, praised the book as "emotionally exhausting and powerful." Ann Cleeves, the festival programming chair, noted the shortlist was "really strong" and highlighted the book's fine writing and tight plot. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career creating the character VI Warshawski, a female private investigator. Paretsky's work has influenced the perception of female writers, and she founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, which affected Worcestershire's hopes of qualifying. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes mentioned that losing Mitch was a significant blow. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy in England. He expressed enjoyment of his time at Worcester and hope to make an impact. In August, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed in 2008 when a speeding car struck him on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev while he tried to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. A coroner in Exeter, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded the death was an unlawful killing, stating that the car had stolen license plates, did not brake, and the driver was speeding. The case highlighted the challenges of investigating deaths abroad. The couple met online in 2006 and married in 2007. Ganna Ziuzina, 19 years younger, was accused of having a motive to inherit Pring's assets, as she claimed to be a teacher but was actually a lap dancer. She sold his property and moved funds from his account. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry, though the case is no longer actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a three-year-old from Merseyside, needs to fly to Seattle, USA for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after a previous transplant failed. His mother, Sophie Fearns, described the treatment as "selfless" and "incredible," highlighting the anonymous donation that covered the costs. The family was left "heartbroken" when the first transplant did not work, but the generous donation provides hope. The treatment will start as soon as possible after financial clearance from the hospital, with the date expected to be confirmed next week.

Apple has introduced two-step verification for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to user accounts, particularly in response to concerns about third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker being used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. The security feature requires users to enter a four-digit code via a trusted phone number or the Find My iPhone app after logging in from a new device. This measure blocks unauthorized access and prevents data backups from being downloaded. However, the feature remains an opt-in choice, with some experts suggesting it should be the default. While Apple's changes have made it more secure against certain hacking techniques, concerns remain about the recovery key's potential for loss or theft. Security experts argue that two-factor authentication should be the default to enhance user security, as single-step verification (passwords) is vulnerable to attacks. Apple is encouraging users to enable two-step verification and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves mentioned that the finer details of a potential deal, where Wright could buy 20% of the club, are not yet finalized. The Sun reported that Wright might become a club director. Billericay Town is eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright, who was runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has played non-league football for several clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed confidence in investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into Sports Direct's warehouse practices. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The letter mentions that Mr Ashley invited the committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but he has not agreed to attend any of the alternative dates offered. The committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons, if Mr Ashley does not respond. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, and the company previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report that was never written, but the colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin, have worked to complete it. The report, titled "Putin. War," is based on facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. It argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, citing evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment playing a decisive role in the conflict. The report includes testimonies from Russian soldiers and evidence of financial incentives for volunteers. It also highlights the lack of compensation for Russian soldiers' families and the challenges in publishing the report. The opposition believes the report could face the same fate as Nemtsov's previous works, which failed to galvanize protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He died from head injuries according to a post-mortem. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are still in custody.

The passage discusses the disagreement between Carwyn Jones, the first minister of Wales, and the UK government regarding the drafting of the Article 50 letter. Jones expressed frustration that he did not receive the letter before its publication and felt that devolved administrations were not respected in the process. He emphasized that the UK government's stated aim was to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but he questioned whether the powers being considered would be accompanied by funding. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the government's approach, stating that they have made their representations and that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole UK. The passage also notes that the specific powers to be devolved remain unclear, and there is uncertainty about whether EU funding will accompany any new powers.

In the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, two cars were damaged during an incident. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed dismay at the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the local community. A post on the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were carrying out their duties when attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's locations and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a San Francisco court filing, the board stated they did not expect him to return to the firm. His lawyer claimed many statements were false, alleging the company invaded his privacy to extort him. The court documents include evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory comments. The company's papers assert that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated its sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board emphasized the significant risk to the company and its shareholders if he were to return. Earlier this month, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage summarizes a basketball game between Greece and Great Britain, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The teams previously faced off in Patras, Greece, earlier this month, with Greece winning 92-64. Three members of the Greek team will be absent in the upcoming game at the Copper Box, providing Great Britain an opportunity for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box, stating it is the level of play needed to prepare for EuroBasket 2017. The game will be Britain's only home game before their EuroBasket 2017 qualifiers in Istanbul, Turkey, starting in September. Following the game, GB will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket begins. The game is scheduled for 17:30-19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website.

The passage reflects on the transformative impact of the iPhone, introduced by Steve Jobs in 2007, which revolutionized the way people use mobile devices. It describes the initial skepticism and the process of obtaining an iPhone for a news report, followed by a reflection on how the iPhone changed the landscape of photography and mobile technology. The author contrasts the early limitations of phone cameras with the advancements made by smartphones, highlighting the iPhone's role in making powerful computers accessible to billions and disrupting various industries. The passage also acknowledges the hyperbolic nature of the iPhone's launch and the subsequent innovations by companies like Amazon and Google. Ultimately, the author expresses gratitude for witnessing the beginning of the mobile connected era.

A charity confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen dying on Monday. Three other cats have died in the last seven days, and another died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, reported that the cat showed signs of illness before dying. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, particularly with the use of antifreeze during this time of year.

The passage discusses the situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is preparing to implement further austerity and liberalization measures, despite previously opposing them. Greece is experiencing a surge in tourism, with Athens airport expecting a significant increase in arrivals. The text questions why Greeks are not protesting against upcoming economic measures, suggesting that the calm may be due to the upcoming revelation of how much Alexis Tsipras has conceded to secure new credit from the eurozone and IMF. The article highlights the economic challenges Greece faces, including the continued partial closure of banks, which hampers business activity and threatens Christmas shopping. The passage also notes that while Syriza has become popular, it has failed to end fiscal austerity, and the new bailout will only be effective if it offers hope for economic recovery. The text calls for creditors to ease Greece's debt burden to facilitate genuine recovery.

Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell in 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara Mitchell's final episodes. Barbara's character, who had a surprise return in 2010, announced she would die from cancer. Kemp will help bring the Mitchell family back together for the last time, with the reunion being a significant moment for the show. Grant Mitchell, a long-standing character in EastEnders, is set to reunite with his brother Phil and mother Barbara, marking a poignant conclusion to his storyline.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October, leading to her death. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed by Northumbria Police about the incident and immediately recognized Dhillon as the perpetrator. The trial revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with Ruggles and stalked her. The parents expressed guilt over trying to reassure Ruggles and their daughter Emma, who warned them about the danger. The parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking and honor their daughter's memory. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The French company EDF has approved £18bn funding for the Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with contracts set to be signed on Friday. However, the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has expressed caution in backing the project. EDF's CEO, Vincent de Rivaz, canceled a trip to Hinkley Point following Clark's comments. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, potential rising costs, and the involvement of foreign governments, with one-third of the project's cost coming from Chinese investors. The government has initiated a further review of the project, which has caused surprise among EDF executives. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity needs. Despite financial concerns and previous resignations within EDF, the company has moved forward with the project. Environmentalists argue that the project is not value for money and that more investment in renewable energy is needed. The Hinkley Point C project has a long history, starting in 2006 with the government's proposal for nuclear energy.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers express concern that this addition may increase conflict and complexity, as it is not typically necessary. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name the person. Despite the guidance indicating that naming is not usually required, some individuals may fill in the box. The new form is intended to make the legal process more user-friendly, especially for those who do not seek legal advice. Adultery was a reason for 12,148 divorces in 2015, while "unreasonable behaviour" was the reason for 46,815. Lawyers warn that naming an adulterous partner can lead to further legal complications and may put the petitioner in a negative light.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental and commercial forestry in Wales. Britain is the world's third-largest wood importer, and ministers aim to encourage commercial forestry investment. Conifer forests have been common in Wales for half a century, contributing to the timber industry. However, Confor warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001, requiring re-planting. Half of the woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales, and the other half by private companies, contributing over £450 million annually to the Welsh economy. There is a conflict between environmental policies promoting native trees and better access for walkers and cyclists, and the commercial interests of forestry. The Welsh government seeks a balance between environmental, economic, and social factors, promoting initiatives like the Glastir scheme. Martin Bishop of Confor argues that environmental aspects are seen as more appealing than commercial forestry and that the current system is too bureaucratic. He highlights the need for 20,000 hectares of new woodland annually to meet targets, as there is a significant market for timber.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, Scotland. Emergency crews responded to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at approximately 16:40. The boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals by Russian Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko to veterans of the Arctic Convoys during a ceremony. Able Seaman Charles Lewis, 91, expressed his honor and delight at receiving the medal. Initially, the Foreign Office prevented Russia from honoring the veterans due to rules against foreign medals given more than five years after an event. The Russian Embassy argued that the Arctic Convoys were vital for the Soviet Union's war effort against Germany. The Arctic Convoys, which operated from Britain to northern Russia, faced significant dangers including U-boat attacks, cold, storms, and ice. Over 104 merchant and 16 military vessels were lost by May 1945, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy had planned to award the Medal of Ushakov to survivors in 2012 but the Foreign Office blocked it. The British Government later created the Arctic Star in 2012 but campaigners wanted the Russian medal. An exception was made, allowing the first medals to be presented during President Vladimir Putin's visit to London in 2013. The Ushakov medal is given to sailors who have shown courage in defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found that delays in getting offenders to start their work and letting them off if they did not attend were significant issues. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours of unpaid work over 17 months. The Ministry of Justice stated it was acting on the report's recommendations. Unpaid work, or "community payback," can range from 40 to 300 hours and is used for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the number of offenders turned away from work when they reported on time and creating objectives that match the offender's circumstances. The chief inspector of probation criticized the lack of focus on delivering and enforcing the sentence, calling for urgent action. The Ministry of Justice emphasized the need for more effective rehabilitation, starting with ensuring offenders attend work and facing consequences if they do not.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding a comedian who is accused of hypocrisy for advocating for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. The comedian, known for his vlogs, has faced such accusations before. When questioned about his living situation during a campaign, he became upset with a journalist and walked off. Although he has not taken legal action against The Sun, he has been critical of its accusations. The comedian acknowledges his wealth and fame but emphasizes his belief in personal change and systemic reform. He argues that the criticism is a form of hypocrisy and that inequality is a pressing issue that needs to be addressed.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite his lack of modesty and his wealth, his work significantly accelerated the human genome sequencing process. After the human genome was published, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the organism Synthia, published in the journal Science. Venter's early life included a shift from academic pursuits to surfing and military service in Vietnam, which inspired his determination to become a doctor and pursue a sense of urgency. He later developed innovative methods for gene sequencing, leading to the creation of Celera Genomics and the first complete genome of a free-living organism. His work, while controversial, has contributed to significant advancements in genomics and synthetic biology, with potential applications in environmental and industrial fields.

A survey of 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school that they hadn't tried at home. Half of the parents said their children had asked for foods from school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents gave packed lunches because they thought their children were too fussy. The Trust and Mumsnet co-founder highlighted the importance of school meals in encouraging children to try new foods and the improvement in school meal quality. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, with more children in Scotland eating school lunches (46%). The survey was conducted online between February 26 and March 5.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer, joined Juventus in 2014 after spending four seasons with Real Madrid. The transfer included an option for Real to buy him back, with the fee estimated at up to 30m euros. Morata has scored three times for Spain at Euro 2016 and has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, helping the club win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, contributing to Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat by Barcelona. Morata, who came through Real's ranks, made his first team debut at 18 and scored 10 goals for Real Madrid.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but has been without a team since being released in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while the remaining 50 stores will be closed. Tesco will loan £80m to the new business, with the total disposal cost estimated at £150m, part of which may be repaid. If the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. The deal is being handled by Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company led by billionaire Ron Burkle. This exit follows Tesco's first annual profit decline in 20 years.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the French Alps covered approximately 375 sq km. By the late 2000s, this area had decreased to about 275 sq km, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. The new French Alps glaciers inventory, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues, showed that the retreat is not uniform, with the greatest losses in the southern sectors. The Belledonne Massif has seen almost complete glacier disappearance, while the Ecrins Massif has experienced more than three times the retreat compared to the Mont Blanc Massif. The retreat is attributed to lower elevation and different climatic conditions in the south. La Mer de Glace, the largest French glacier, has slightly decreased in area. The study was presented at the AGU Fall Meeting and highlights ongoing efforts to monitor glacier health in the Alps.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers so far and are hosting Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, knowing a victory would almost guarantee their place in the next major competition. However, Evans is determined not to miss out after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the 2018 World Cup. Iceland, ranked 20th in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins, and the outcome of their upcoming matches could determine who tops the group. Scotland is in a strong position to reach the finals in the Netherlands without a play-off, as the best six of the eight group runners-up automatically qualify. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals and the impact of having fans at Falkirk. She also highlights the benefits of having players from top leagues like Germany, which has developed women's football significantly, and how this experience enhances the national team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London complained of harassment over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, claimed the allegations were based on some tweets that he described as not threatening. He accused the media of using "innuendo" to encourage speculation. Campbell, who is a vocal advocate for Scottish independence, has been posting less frequently on his blog due to "reasons totally outwith my control." The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegations of online harassment, which the woman reported to a south London police station. Campbell has been bailed pending further inquiries until mid-September. In a statement, he clarified that the alleged events relate entirely to some tweets from his Twitter account, which are still publicly visible and not threatening.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908, is a well-known symbol of Skegness. Peta argues that Jolly evokes images of animal cruelty, while the mayor, Carl Macey, states that Jolly is widely accepted as happy and friendly and does not represent animal cruelty. The mayor mentioned that Peta's suggestion will be considered by the council, but if it is not broken, they will not attempt to fix it.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, where they scored multiple tries and dominated possession. The Scots took an early lead with a try from Tommy Seymour, followed by additional tries from Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, and Hamish Watson. Georgia scored a try from Vasil Lobzhanidze but could not maintain their momentum. Scotland's performance was highlighted by their strong possession and effective counter-attacks, with Greig Laidlaw converting several tries. The Scottish team's coach, Vern Cotter, praised their strategy and execution, noting their ability to control the game and score points effectively. The final score was not explicitly stated, but Scotland's dominant performance led to a significant lead.

Widnes secured a 44-22 victory over Castleford, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge giving them a 14-6 half-time lead. Despite Castleford's efforts, including tries from Paddy Flynn, Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick, Widnes held on to win. The Vikings moved above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth. The match saw Widnes' defense falter, allowing Patrick to score, but they managed to maintain their lead. Castleford's players included Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, and McMeeken, with replacements Millington, Springer, Tickle, and Cook. Widnes' players included Hanbury, Thompson, Runciman, Bridge, Ah Van, Mellor, Brown, Cahill, White, Buchanan, Whitley, Dean, and Leuluai, with replacements J. Chapelhow, Manuokafoa, Walker, and Heremaia. The referee was J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old detainee at Guantanamo Bay, was released after a US review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been detained since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. Al-Odah's release came after a July decision by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board, and he is now expected to spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. This marks the first inmate release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. Al-Odah's release reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility, opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, has been a focus of President Barack Obama's promise to shut it down.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, the Gallipoli landings. Thousands attended services at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey, with a parade and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The day is significant for expatriates and visitors, honoring the sacrifices of Australians and New Zealanders in all wars. Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds, reflecting on the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. The ceremony included prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the bloodiest operations of the war.

Clarkson, 30, has joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mainly played as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has been capped twice for Scotland and has one international goal, has made almost 400 senior appearances. His previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa. Clarkson is ready for his debut and aims to help the team win games to boost confidence and improve their position in the table.

The turkey firm was sold to Ranjit Boparan, a food tycoon, who has confirmed that the existing pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews will continue under the new ownership. Unite, the union, reported that productive talks were held, and guarantees were given that all current agreements would be honored. The union also noted that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current members have an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken.

The passage discusses the problems faced by a new ferry service in Cowes, including technical issues, delays, and damage to vehicles and local businesses. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July to address the issues and gather feedback. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation for local businesses and damaged cars is under discussion, and he noted that the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems, which have been addressed. The council authorized ramp extensions to resolve vehicle scraping issues and groundings were resolved through improved seamanship.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that fishing regions around the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU during the referendum. The Lords review warns that these communities may be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been viewed as detrimental to the UK fishing industry, but Brexit is seen by some as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. The report notes that the UK fishing industry is a low priority for the government but must not be marginalized. The industry faces challenges due to shared fish stocks with EU coastal states and the need for continued market access. The report suggests that post-Brexit, the UK should retain elements of the CFP and continue to cooperate with neighboring states. There is concern about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these challenges, the fishing industry remains optimistic about the future post-Brexit, with some analysts viewing the recent EU quota agreement as a positive sign. The UK government emphasizes the opportunity to review fisheries management for fair access to quotas, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was placed on a community payback order and the sex offenders register. Following a hearing by the General Teaching Council Scotland, he was removed from the professional register due to his conduct being "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher. The panel found his behavior inconsistent with professional standards and concluded there was a strong likelihood of recurring offending behavior. Geaney, who was 69 at the time, was prohibited from re-registering for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at the site on Duncan Street following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The company, operated by Asset and Land Group, could not be contacted for a comment and has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. Concerns were raised about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment, leading the Environment Agency to revoke the environmental permit, which takes effect on 7 August after any appeal. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is attempting to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims rebels have taken control of the prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and only 4% have left the country. The US and Russia have expressed concerns about the slow progress of the destruction plan, with Russia urging Syria to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by 1 March. The Syrian government insists it is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the UN Security Council and the OPCW.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a second-largest run margin in their history against Pakistan. The hosts scored 589-8 and 173-1, with Joe Root performing exceptionally well, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Root was named man of the match, and captain Alastair Cook praised his performance. England's bowling and batting were highlighted as key factors in the win, with Pakistan's batting struggling, especially in the first innings where they batted for only 63 overs. Despite the loss, Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, citing poor shot selection and a lack of confidence. The series is expected to be closely contested, with England likely to win again. Pakistan will play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales. The review aims to gather experiences from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of including the voices of older people and those who care for them in her work. She has met with many older people in residential care and has seen the positive impact of high-quality care. However, she has also received concerns about unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira's team will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review but expresses disappointment that no care home expert is on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder, has been player-manager of Arbroath since 2010 and has been appointed as the new manager of Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing the 2013-14 season at the bottom of League One. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process. Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and also featured for Östersunds in Sweden, won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Swansea City will be managed by Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams in their match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club aims to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Swansea's current manager, Curtis, believes the team is capable of staying in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of maintaining the club's identity and history. Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after overcoming financial difficulties and a near-relegation in 2003. Curtis feels the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and believes the team's identity has been diluted by frequent managerial changes. He also mentions that new signings are made aware of the club's history through a documentary, which helps instill a sense of passion and commitment to staying in the top flight.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite his lack of modesty and his wealth, his work significantly accelerated the genome mapping process. After the human genome was published, Venter focused on creating synthetic life, culminating in the creation of an organism called Synthia. His early life experiences, including his time in Vietnam, inspired his sense of urgency and determination. Venter's innovative approach to genetic research, including focusing on RNA rather than DNA, led to significant advancements. He faced criticism and financial challenges, leading him to establish private research institutions. Venter's work also included exploring oceanic life forms to sequence genomes and contribute to understanding gene evolution. His synthetic life project, while controversial, aimed to create a new industrial revolution by using synthetic microbes to reduce environmental impact.

The Sutton Trust, in a report commissioned by Boston Consulting Group, warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, with only around 200,000 of the 520,000 starting each year rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. The report highlights that England's vocational system is fragmented, with 18,000 different qualifications compared to Germany's 330, and that over half of apprenticeships are below level three. It calls for a significant expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, prioritizing level three and four courses. The report criticizes the current system for not providing good job prospects for young people and suggests that the expansion should focus on creating high-quality, respected vocational routes. The Department for Education states that apprenticeships are being reformed to improve standards, while the Association of Colleges expresses concerns about the feasibility of creating 300,000 new apprenticeships given existing shortages.

The British athlete, Storey, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. She is aiming to win her 17th title in the upcoming road race. Storey, a 37-year-old, is targeting further Paralympic success at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals from six Paralympics. She has won 21 world titles across both cycling and swimming. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005. She also won four golds at the 2012 Paralympics in London.

The Bulls faced financial difficulties that led to their expulsion from the Football Conference. After failing to meet payment deadlines to their football creditors, the Conference expelled them, and Chester City was reinstated as a Conference Premier club. Hereford United's efforts to stay in the Conference Premier on the final day of the season were unsuccessful, and the club's financial issues, including debts of £148,000, contributed to their expulsion. The club was taken over by Tommy Agombar, and the Hereford United Supporters' Trust had previously offered to buy the club for £1 to clear debts. The financial struggles of Hereford have been exacerbated by falling attendance and a downward spiral since their relegation from the Football League in 2012.

The former Manchester City player, now 30, has earned 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was part of two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, making his debut in 2004. He scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after several months of illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood worked with numerous leading orchestras globally and was a key exponent of the early-music movement. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for over 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced more than 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Among his notable recordings is the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and later with other notable musicians. He held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He was also the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic positions at Harvard, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell. His legacy is remembered by colleagues and former students, who praised his generosity, academic abilities, and contributions to historically informed music.

The passage describes a boy from Northern Ireland who is struggling in mainstream schooling and has been placed in a special school. His family is concerned about his isolation and the lack of available places in special schools. The boy's mother expressed worries about the system isolating him further. An extra classroom assistant has been added to a local special school, offering hope for the boy's placement in the next few weeks. However, the family is concerned that this situation may affect other families due to the system's capacity issues. The Education Authority acknowledged the concerns but could not comment on individual cases, stating they are reviewing the need for special school places and aiming to ensure availability close to where children reside.

Newport Gwent Dragons are under a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The county has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and has priority for fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on in early May. In 2013, the Exiles secured a 10-year lease after promotion to the Football League. Both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points above the relegation zone with two games remaining and has the opportunity to secure survival this weekend. Foxall emphasized that relegation would be a significant blow for both the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage describes a person's experiences during the civil war in Sierra Leone, which ended in 2002. He was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at 15 and endured harsh treatment, including physical abuse and threats. He eventually escaped and was caught, but met a preacher who helped him rebuild his life and continue his education. The person later became involved in the 2014 Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, where he and others worked to educate people about the virus, provide support, and establish an Ebola treatment unit. The passage also includes statistics on Ebola deaths in different countries.

The passage describes a situation where approximately 80,000 art pieces, including ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, were at risk of being auctioned to settle a pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign, led by The Art Fund, successfully raised the needed funds in just one month. The collection will remain on display at the Barlaston Museum, then be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was made possible through public support and negotiations. The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension debt after the company's collapse in 2009, and the collection was at risk of being sold and scattered globally without the fundraising effort. The collection is significant to Staffordshire's cultural heritage and plays a key role in Britain's national identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the finer details of a potential deal, where Wright could buy 20% of the club, are not yet finalized. The Sun reported that Wright might become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, who was runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has played non-league football for several clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed confidence in investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in a match. Blackpool took the lead when Nathan Delfouneso played a pinpoint chip, and Jamille Matt scored. Colchester equalized when Kurtis Guthrie scored from a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool had chances to win, including a missed opportunity by Tom Aldred. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The Fawley power station chimney, which was 198 meters high, will be the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. It is set to be the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside, which includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, which was commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation, was capable of powering one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, and the company plans to use the existing infrastructure with minimal investment to create a spectacular attraction.

In the Hong Kong championships, GB's 23-year-old rider, Latham, won bronze in the men's individual pursuit, earning the team's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham chased down Polish rider Adrian Teklinski and German rider Lucass Liss to secure bronze. In the men's team pursuit, GB were beaten by Italy for bronze. Meanwhile, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, Joe Truman, was outclassed in his semi-final. In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, joined the team for the quartet, but the young squad did not secure a medal. Barker expressed optimism about their progress. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the women's sprint, feeling she was missing a bit of her form. She will compete in two more events.

Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, is returning to EastEnders for Barbara Mitchell's final episodes. Barbara's character, who had left in 2010, will die from cancer in emotional scenes set to air in the spring. Kemp will help bring the Mitchell family back together, with the storyline involving the reunion of the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time. Grant Mitchell, a long-standing character in EastEnders, is set to return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reunite with his brother.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Tottenham (Spurs) struggled against Liverpool (Anfield). Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire to win, stating it makes it difficult to challenge for the Premier League. Chelsea could extend their lead at the top if they beat Burnley. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning only twice since September 24, and have a poor record against top-six teams away from home. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy commented on Spurs' defensive issues and lack of pace when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP lost the presidential election for the first time, and APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP's decline was reinforced by election results, including losing key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and control of Adamawa, which was badly affected by Boko Haram. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's victory signifies a historic shift, relegating the PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to gain national support, performing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Most northern states and Lagos went to the APC, but the APC did not win any of the five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari. The elections were generally peaceful, with some violence in southern states. The PDP is expected to undergo introspection and rebuilding under a new leader, as voters felt the need for change after 16 years of rule. The PDP also faced allegations of corruption and failure to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to access online information, including videos, band interviews, and details about the festival. The festival is introducing an augmented reality experience to enhance the visitor's enjoyment and allow people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere at any time. The app will provide updated information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's unique atmosphere. This year's acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, which were rated inadequate by Ofsted. The trusts may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, face potential funding loss unless concerns are addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools mentioned parents trying to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The Education Minister, Lord Nash, expressed deep concerns about the management of Park View School and sent letters to the trusts, demanding actions such as ending less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, ceasing segregation, and creating a more balanced curriculum. The trusts have been given until 4 July to respond. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that optometrist Honey Rose's conduct fell far below expected standards and was "criminal," leading to Vinnie's death. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution argues that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test, which could have led to further investigation and prevented his death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg set up meetings between a woman and a man he found through an adult website, filmed them having sex, and sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing the woman to engage in sexual activity with the man between September 2013 and September 2014, and of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images. He was also convicted of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on December 25, 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and was found guilty despite denying the charges. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. The judge noted that Weatherhogg, a first offender, posed a moderate risk of re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 against Afghanistan in the first T20, with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and William Porterfield (39) contributing significantly. However, Afghanistan chased down the target with 171-4, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). The sides will face each other again in the second T20 on Friday. Ireland faced early challenges, including the loss of opener Paul Stirling for a duck, and the absence of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back injury. Rankin is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

FC Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club has stated they did not commit any offense and have made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to address possible interpretations of tax responsibility. The total cost of Neymar to the club, including other fees, is estimated at £106.8m. Barcelona is under investigation for potential misappropriation of funds, but denies any wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has ruled there is enough evidence to continue the investigation. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives, working with Thai police, investigated the murders of the two victims. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are alleged to have confessed to the killings. Thai police have denied reports that the suspects have withdrawn their confessions. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, specifically regarding DNA sample verification and allegations of mistreatment. UK detectives have completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police stated that DNA found on Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are hosting Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, knowing a win would secure their place in the finals. Evans is determined not to miss out after previous play-off losses, emphasizing the emotional significance of reaching the finals. Iceland, ranked 20th, are also unbeaten and the outcome of their upcoming matches will decide the group top. Scotland is in a strong position to reach the finals without a play-off, with the best six group runners-up qualifying automatically. Evans, a Bayern Munich player, highlights the benefits of having players in top leagues, which enhance the national team's performance. She believes the experience and exposure from playing abroad contribute to the team's success.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of two-step verification for iCloud, which adds an extra security layer by requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app. This measure prevents unauthorized access to iCloud and restricts purchases from the App Store, iTunes, or iBooks if the code is not entered. The security feature is currently an opt-in choice, but experts suggest it should be the default. The passage also highlights how this change addresses a security vulnerability previously exploited by hackers using Elcomsoft's software to access iCloud data. While Apple's new security measures are considered effective, concerns remain about the recovery key's potential loss or theft. Experts argue that two-factor authentication should be the default for all major tech companies to enhance user security.

In the May election, UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour spent £1,027,339. The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. UKIP's campaign spending was 68p per vote, while Labour's was 26p, the Conservatives' was 79p, and the Lib Dems' was £1.45 per vote. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, 27, has agreed to join Barrow's National League rivals by mutual consent after cancelling his contract. He will play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, is set to join the Gulls after being recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He was treated by veterinary staff but was pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, noted that such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. His trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime." Although Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, he had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on the day of the race. The report concludes that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage, not linked to his previous health issues.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several Scottish Parliament members before the election on 5 May. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotionally moved by the speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the importance of the parliament's role in governance. He acknowledged the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized the bill for not meeting unionist politicians' pledges. Salmond also made light-hearted jokes about the UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse. Duncan McNeil, stepping down after 20 years, warned Holyrood about learning from Westminster's committee system. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about missing her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage provides the following core information: 

- A star will play Mrs Potts, the teapot housekeeper voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version of the film. 
- Kevin Kline has signed on to play Maurice, the father of Belle. 
- The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. 
- Emma Watson has been cast as Belle. 
- Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will co-star as Gaston. 
- Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. 
- Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will hold a meeting with victims' relatives to announce its decisions regarding charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster. Ninety-six football fans died in the disaster, and new inquests concluded they were unlawfully killed. Files involving 23 suspects were referred to the CPS, with 15 related to an investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 related to a police conduct inquiry. Relatives are invited to a meeting where they will be informed of the CPS's decisions by Sue Hemming. Margaret Aspinall, a relative, expressed that the process has been a long struggle, and the families remain determined to achieve accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with a former inmate stating the prison is known for a high influx of contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice emphasized that staff are working hard to prevent contraband but acknowledged more needs to be done, prompting the Justice Secretary to review measures to address the issue. A nearby resident reported witnessing such incidents four times in two weeks and mentioned the prison is holding an evening event to discuss responses. The Ministry of Justice denied drone use for smuggling and noted that laws allow up to two years in prison for those smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright, 55, while she was on duty outside Bedford Road Lower School. Wright, who denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, admitted striking Blackburn but claims he was blinded by the setting sun and failed to stop for a red light. Blackburn is now in residential care. During the trial, Wright expressed remorse for his actions and described how his actions had impacted Sylvia and her family. The court heard that the sun was 10 minutes from setting, which could have been shining into Wright's eyes. The trial is ongoing.

Muir has decided to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over competing with the Scotland team at the Commonwealth Games in April, as her exams are scheduled for May. She will return to university next week and will not be able to participate in the event. Despite this, she expressed her love for running for Scotland and the significance of the Commonwealth Games. Muir is optimistic about her future in athletics, mentioning she may have several more Olympics in her career. She also mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir's personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m was achieved during the event, and she was pleased with her performance.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a site in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday, involving excavations and expected to take several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed Mr. Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland. Detectives released the footage in April and appealed for the man to come forward, believing he was the same man captured on CCTV later on Haddington Road. The man has not yet been identified, and gardaí renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro defeated Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in a grueling match, marking his first Grand Slam victory since the 2014 Australian Open. Del Potro, ranked 165th, is playing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after recovering from injury. He will next face Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro expressed happiness and relief after his win, feeling alive again after two years of struggles. Nick Kyrgios also advanced in his half of the draw, facing Feliciano Lopez in the third round. Other players like Berdych and Tsonga also had routine victories.

Tunisia was at risk of being expelled from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after criticizing the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints made during the 2015 Nations Cup. However, they apologized to Caf, leading to their reinstatement. Morocco was also able to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on their participation. Morocco was previously banned after being replaced as hosts of the 2015 Nations Cup due to concerns over the Ebola virus, and they were given a reduced fine. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 finals. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was also in doubt until they met with Caf president Issa Hayatou, leading to a reconciliation. Tunisia and Morocco are now in their respective groups for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia potentially setting a record for consecutive participations if they reach the finals.

McLaren, with a rich history of 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline in performance. The team's recent struggles are attributed to issues with the Honda power unit, despite having a strong car. McLaren's history includes periods of dominance, such as the 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and the 1998-99 success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines. The team has faced scandals, including a $100 million fine in 2007 and 'lie-gate' in 2010. Ron Dennis, the team's long-time figurehead, believes McLaren is on the cusp of a resurgence, with Fernando Alonso's return in 2015 and the potential for a renewed Honda partnership to bring success back to the team.

A paramedic was called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge noted O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed concern about not having the power to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

stephen curry broke his own nba three-point record during a 116-105 victory over the portland trail blazers, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers. he joined klay thompson in helping the golden state warriors avoid their first three-game losing streak. lamarcus aldridge and damian lillard led the blazers with 27 and 20 points respectively. in another game, the chicago bulls defeated the miami heat 89-78, with pau gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds, and derrick rose contributing 12 points as he continued his recovery from injury.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. The players believed van Velzen was a competition winner who would provide a dead-ball masterclass. However, van Velzen showcased his free-kick skills, impressing the players. Van Velzen, a YouTube sensation known for his free-kick videos, had a memorable experience meeting the Liverpool players. He also revealed Balotelli's infamous slogan, as Balotelli had worn the slogan's T-shirt during a match.

Angelina Jolie, a carrier of the BRCA1 gene, reduced her risk of death from breast cancer by having her ovaries removed, known as an oophorectomy. A study found that women with the BRCA1 mutation who underwent oophorectomy after breast cancer diagnosis had a 62% reduction in breast cancer death risk. The study analyzed 676 patients, with nearly half undergoing oophorectomy. Women with BRCA1 mutations had a 70% lifetime risk of breast cancer, and oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in all-cause mortality. The procedure was particularly effective for those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered part of treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. Jolie, who had a double mastectomy and oophorectomy, stated that the procedure did not affect her sense of womanhood. The BRCA1 mutation is more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population, and genetic testing is available for those at risk.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter morning as they lingered on the tracks in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am on Sunday, involving train number 80, the Carolinian, which was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. The train was on property owned by Norfolk Southern. Authorities confirmed that none of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route. A man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal mentioned that they may have lived in a homeless camp and asked for help crossing the railroad tracks. Durham is located about 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, Raleigh. The typical trip from Charlotte to New York City takes around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin cartel and a 27-year DEA undercover operative, is facing deportation from the United States after retiring due to declining health. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his cooperation but has not received it, leaving him in a legal limbo. Toro, who helped dismantle the Medellin cartel and aided in the prosecution of Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, is now living illegally in the U.S. and is preparing to go into hiding if deported. He expressed fear of being sent back to Colombia, where he would face danger, and criticized the DEA for not fulfilling its promise of citizenship. Toro has received financial support from a former colleague but remains unable to secure a green card or passport, and cannot collect social security benefits.

The US body that regulates internet addresses is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the '.sucks' domain to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities and companies. The '.sucks' domain has been used by major brands such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo. Kevin Spacey is among the celebrities who have paid to have their names removed from the '.sucks' domain. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now backtracking after concerns from industry groups. The advisory panel has called the practice a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." Vox Populi recommends charging $2,499 a year for the '.sucks' domain, with resellers selling them for around $2,000 a year. ICANN is seeking remedies if it is found that Vox Populi's actions are illegal.

A mother of a baby boy was arrested 27 years after his body was found in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a village pond. Police exhumed the body from a grave in Norfolk after a case review, and a DNA sample led them to the mother. The woman, who had concealed her pregnancy from her family and friends, admitted the baby was stillborn and placed the body in the pond on June 5, 1988. The case was unsolved for 27 years until DNA technology allowed identification of the mother. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter's church, named Peter after the church. Police ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides on charges. A support group helped raise funds for a new headstone, and the case highlights the emotional impact of stillbirth and the importance of support for families in similar situations.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving car. Hicks, 23 at the time, was on his way home from a night out in Bath with his girlfriend when he was taken against his will by Young, who mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to flee. Young drove Hicks for almost a mile before he jumped out of the car, which was traveling at over 20mph, resulting in severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and a need for round-the-clock care. A judge ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, allowing him to claim damages. The compensation is expected to be around 50% of the family's requested amount, with further details to be determined in a subsequent hearing. The case highlights the significant risk to life and limb from such conduct.

Wednesday night saw tornado sirens blaring in Kansas as several storms reported twisters. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned about the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, including three sightings near Aetna. Kansas was not the only state affected, with a potential tornado reported in Potosi, Missouri, and reports of wind damage and flooding. Other areas, like Farmington, experienced significant hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago. Rockhold plans to dominate Machida by cutting him off and forcing him into a disadvantaged position, leveraging his own skills and speed. Machida, confident in his ability to win, believes he can upset Rockhold and secure a title shot. Both fighters express mutual respect for each other's styles, but Rockhold is focused on winning the fight. Rockhold's last victory was against Michael Bisping, while Machida's last victory was against CB Dollaway. Both fighters are well-prepared for the match.

The passage describes a incident where a light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, resulting in a belly landing. The aircraft, identified as an Aerostar, was captured in Fort Pierce, Florida, approaching the Aero Acres residential airpark. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, was flying the plane and had not deployed the landing gear before touchdown, leading to a collision with the runway. The plane's propellers were damaged, and it made a loud impact sound. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where it landed safely. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the incident. The most common causes of a gear-up landing are human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted he is disappointed with Yaya Toure's performance but will support the midfielder until the end of the season.
