Manchester City are considering selling Toure as they aim to overhaul their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his contract, has faced criticism for his underperformance this season. Pellegrini emphasized that Toure does not need a break and will receive his support throughout the season. Additionally, Manchester City will face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany, who may miss the rest of the campaign due to a muscle injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the team's struggles and emphasized that players should take responsibility for their performances. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other players by moving to Manchester City, as the club is interested in signing the West Ham left back.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. However, his case expired in October 2014, and his European Arrest Warrant was withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law allows for the sentence to be extinguished if more than double the penalty period has passed. The Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction, and Rancadore's solicitor is confident that the Italian government will withdraw the extradition request. The case will now be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, and Rancadore will be allowed to remain in the UK. The extradition process was criticized for being lengthy and costly, with legal experts expressing frustration over the delays and the unnecessary proceedings. Rancadore has lived in the UK for over 20 years under the name Marc Skinner and has been described as a quiet, family-oriented man.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He will be ridden by AP McCoy, who will have six rivals in the race. This is McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalised until Friday morning. Mr. Mole was previously ridden to victory at Newbury in February, after which McCoy unexpectedly announced his intention to quit riding. Other runners in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The mother of a girl murdered 40 years ago, Virginia Trimble Ritter, has recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body and expressed a desire for revenge. Her daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and her mother was advised against seeing the body and crime scene photos. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and received a 44-year sentence. The case was one of Nashville's most notorious unsolved murders for 33 years, and Barrett was later arrested in 2006 due to a DNA match from another murder case.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters to complete the career grand slam. He has revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career. McIlroy is aiming to win his first Green Jacket and become the sixth player to win all four major titles. He is looking to achieve this at the Masters later this month. McIlroy has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances but is determined to win the tournament. He has previously won the U.S. Open and the PGA Championship, and is hoping to emulate Jack Nicklaus by winning all four majors. McIlroy has faced challenges, including a legal dispute and the cancellation of his wedding, but is determined to use the golf course as a sanctuary from the pressure. He believes that winning the Masters would be a significant achievement in his career.

This week, several trending stories captured public attention. Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain, with a fashion company CEO snapping the photo. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common, despite a crackdown on vice. RDJ became agitated during an interview about his private life. A new trend, lip plumping by sucking on a jar to resemble Kylie Jenner, gained popularity with the #KylieJennerChallenge. A 102-year-old woman traveled back in time with the help of filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs sparked controversy over alleged racism. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," drawing social media interest. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer. Referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" became a way to announce pregnancy. A military dad photobombed his son, earning praise for originality. All these stories trended this week.

Hundreds of children were admitted to hospital last year after being born with brain damage due to alcohol exposure in the womb, according to new figures. In England, 272 youngsters with fetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized over the past 12 months. Experts warn the actual number could be higher. Research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical issues from alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 cases annually. A 15-year-old girl named Niamh Brown, born with fetal alcohol syndrome, requires assistance with daily tasks and will never live independently. The National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome highlights the under-diagnosis of the condition. Other medical issues linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol intake to two units no more than twice a week, but experts suggest complete abstinence during pregnancy.

A 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, also known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," was jailed after attempting to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. He entered the post office and stores at 8 pm on March 15, waving an axe and demanding cash from a terrified assistant. The shop owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled Mckerry, causing him to fall and drop the axe. Mckerry's wife, Sam Dhillon, then hit him with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. Mckerry was arrested by police shortly after and previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery. He had a history of criminal activity, including shoplifting and burglary, and had been arrested multiple times in his youth. Mckerry was jailed for six years after the hearing.

Four Royal Navy sailors were charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party held at a Canadian naval barracks. They must remain in Nova Scotia until they are tried. The sailors, including Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, were given identical bail conditions that require them to live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax. They must surrender their passports, continue working for the Royal Navy, and not leave Nova Scotia. The alleged sexual assault occurred after the sailors returned from a hockey game. The case is still in an early investigative stage, and additional charges may result from forensic tests. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, from Las Vegas, is accused of child abuse after a stranger reported her for allegedly scalding her four-year-old son, RJ Jackson, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red, scaly, and inflamed. RJ is one of only 70 people in the world with this condition. Valerie has been regularly applying creams to manage his skin condition, but she was surrounded by armed police after a member of the public mistakenly believed his skin condition was a sign of abuse. Valerie and her husband, Reginald, have had to deal with cruel taunts and bullying from others, as well as being denied entry to places like a playhouse due to his skin condition. The condition, a more extreme form of ichthyosis, can be misdiagnosed until later in a child's life, and there is no cure, though symptoms often improve with time. Valerie found information about Netherton's syndrome through a Facebook group and has since become an advocate for awareness about the condition.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding controversial posters by the online fitness store Protein World, which featured a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield on the London Underground. The posters, featuring the slogan "Are you beach body ready?", sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures and over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. The posters were eventually removed by Transport for London (TFL) after the three-week advertising period concluded, despite the negative public reaction. The campaign also faced protests and social media backlash, with some users criticizing the ads for promoting an unhealthy body image. Protein World defended their campaign, stating their goal was to encourage healthier lifestyles, while also facing threats, including a bomb threat. The company's advertising methods were not changed, and sales of protein powder in the UK are expected to grow significantly in the coming years.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes, including up to an 87% increase, just ten days after the general election, despite political pledges to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his constituency. Cameron has pledged to freeze fares in real terms for the next parliament, while Labour has also pledged a price hike cap. The fare increase for a return ticket from Charlbury to London will rise from £33.30 to £62.40, an 87% increase, starting May 17. Other rail companies are also introducing price hikes, with some increases reaching up to 24.5% or 22%. Virgin has defended its fare increases, stating that most affect Virgin trains-only fares, which are cheaper than those offered by rival firms.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being hit in the face with a brick by thugs who had been throwing stones at his property in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred when Young confronted the attackers at his front door, resulting in serious injuries, including an open wound to his forehead and a severe injury to his left eye. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The attack happened three weeks after the couple, who met 14 months ago, got married. Police have launched an investigation but have found no motive, suggesting it may have been a case of youths "messing around." The couple now plans to move out of the area due to safety concerns.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from a leg injury sustained in a road accident that also resulted in the death of his father. Poynton missed the entire 2014 campaign but made a comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and dedication, stating that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform this summer. Poynton is now committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, has been told he is cancer-free after a year of treatment. Harley, who was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck, used a superhero mask inspired by the Ninja Turtles to help him feel brave during his radiotherapy treatment. His story gained international attention, leading to a gift from Nickelodeon and recognition from Cancer Research UK. Harley underwent 80 days of chemotherapy, an operation, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, and is now cancer-free. He will have regular check-ups and is expected to return to school. His family is overjoyed and hopeful for the future.

Jack Grealish must focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, according to Tim Sherwood. Grealish impressed in Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool and is currently wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to continue performing well for Villa to secure his place in the first team. Grealish is expected to decide between Ireland and England at the end of the season, with his father advising him to concentrate on club football first. The decision is ultimately up to Grealish, who needs to play more for Villa before making his choice.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at airports for private jet travelers, highlighting that these fees can vary significantly, with some airports charging thousands of dollars per landing. It mentions that these fees provide insight into the popularity of certain transport hubs for the wealthy. The passage also notes that traveling by private jet is a growing trend, with significant market values in the US and Europe. It provides examples of high landing fees at various airports, including some in Japan, such as Haneda Airport, which is the most expensive. The passage also gives examples of specific routes and costs, including the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix as some of the most expensive times to fly.

Cooper, a Labrador Retriever, is known for eating very quickly, as noted by Katie Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort. In a video, Cooper eats an ice cream cone in one bite while his companion Daisy takes only a few licks. Gallegos ensures Daisy gets her fill first due to Cooper's fast eating habit. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Additionally, the duo has been seen at a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," where Cooper also finishes the drink quickly. Gallegos explains that the Starbucks beverage is just whip cream in a cup. Some viewers find the scene cute and humorous, while others criticize the feeding practice, but Gallegos defends it, stating that Cooper is healthy and that she feeds him ice cream similarly to how she once fed her late dog Sammy.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after signing a three-year deal. He previously joined the club as an assistant manager to Allan Johnston but took control of the team when his former team-mate quit in early February. Locke, who will speak at a press conference on Friday morning, has lost only once in seven games since taking over at Rugby Park.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because he wears essential oils from Doterra to help him stay calm and focused. The school warned that the oils, which have a strong scent, could be a distraction to other students. Despite the threat, Kemp insists the oils have a positive impact on her son and continues to fight the decision. The school district later stated they would not suspend Logan, citing it as a "health issue." The family uses Doterra oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was completely destroyed by a fire that spread through 90 condos. The fire, which began on Wednesday at 3 pm, was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and produced smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews were deployed, but they could not get inside the buildings. The fire is being investigated, with claims that it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November. Residents described the fire as devastating, with one resident stating, "this is something that you think happens to other people, but when it happens to yourself, it's just unbelievable." The building manager, Rob Taber, said he has lost everything.

The passage discusses Queen Elizabeth II's love for riding and her connection with horses. She is 88 years old and was spotted riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She prefers to ride without a helmet, using a silk scarf instead, and has never worn a riding helmet. The Queen has a long history with horses, starting at the age of four with a Shetland pony named Peggy. She has ridden various horses over the years, including Betsy in the 1950s and Surprise in 1961. Although she has reduced her riding due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court. The passage also provides information about the history of fell ponies, which have been around since the Neolithic period and were used by various cultures, including the Romans and Vikings.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in a tragic outcome, with one man killed and the other charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from Phillip Pama, 28, during an argument. Yeaman was making a lot of noise in his yard on Muller Road around 9 PM on Thursday night. Pama, who works a 3 AM shift and was sleeping at the time, confronted Yeaman, leading to the escalation. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama hit Yeaman blindly, not seeing the punch connect but feeling it. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 PM. Pama was granted conditional bail, ordered to surrender his passport, follow a curfew, and report to the police station twice a week. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18. Neighbors described Yeaman as kind and generous, though he was known for getting drunk and playing loud music. Pama, a father of three, has no history of violence and was reportedly upset with grief.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, sought to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-boyfriend, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. During a sting operation in Russia, an undercover police officer posed as a hitman and filmed Simonova ordering the hit. She requested that the victim be tortured and killed, specifying that he should be broken and bleed to death. Simonova was arrested after handing over some of the money for the hit and faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Damian Vanya, who ended the relationship with Simonova for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped that Simonova would be imprisoned for a long time.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, has a strong faith in God and prays every day, though he does not go to church regularly. He emphasizes separating his professional and personal life, stating he never prays about football or discusses it with his wife. Mourinho and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger and have experienced poverty. He describes himself as a good person, with a strong family life and positive relationships. Mourinho is currently leading Chelsea, who are top of the league, and has faced some controversies, including a fine for making claims about a campaign against the club. His son celebrates Chelsea's victories, and he maintains a balance between his professional and personal life.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker returned to hosting "The Price is Right," taking over the show on the April 1 edition alongside Drew Carey. At 91, Barker handled the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before passing hosting duties to Carey. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker did not seem to miss a beat.

an off-duty secret service agent, arthur baldwin, was arrested in washington d.c. after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. he was taken into custody by the metropolitan police and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. the agency revoked his security clearance and put him on leave. baldwin is posted to the foreign missions branch, which works with the state department. court records show he was to be arraigned friday afternoon, but no attorney was listed. this arrest follows another incident where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for misconduct, and the homeland security department's inspector general is investigating both cases. this marks another setback for the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a close-up image of a hungry lion at the city's Safari Park. He approached the lion from a distance, creeping within 10 feet, and managed to take a few photos with only a camera. However, the sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to retreat quickly. He described the experience as a close call, where the lion treated him like prey, and he was forced to scramble into his car to safety. Saeed reflected on the incident, acknowledging the danger and stating he would not attempt it again.

new york city police have released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died in brooklyn last month. the woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on march 22 in the gravesend section of brooklyn. the tattoo, identified as the name "monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose, is believed to be faded. police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are asking the public for information about the woman.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. They couldn't afford a full-sized lot, so they constructed the home over a year and a half, using a steel frame and wood. The home is nearly self-sufficient, with solar power, a wood-fired stove, and water from a nearby spring. The couple now live in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature, with a cozy, wood-lined home and a babbling brook nearby. The project cost about $25,000, and they plan to build another one in the future.

A study found that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not. Researchers, including Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University, discovered that kindergarten students who shared iPads over an academic year scored around 30 points higher than students who used the devices individually or did not use them. The study, which involved 352 students, suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology is key to the improved results. Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness. Her findings are set to be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association.

This little piggy, born without back legs, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front legs. The piglet, nicknamed 'Super Pig,' balances on its front trotters and has captured the hearts of thousands through a video showing it learning to walk. The piglet, belonging to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, mixes happily with its littermates, all of whom have four legs. The piglet's ability to balance on two legs has attracted villagers and tourists, and it is not the first animal in China to gain attention for walking on two legs, as a rabbit at a zoo in Liuzhou also became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was struck by a car during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was hit when Francesco Dracone's car spun while exiting the pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg injury and was released after treatment at the infield care center. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd. The race was affected by rain, which caused many cars to struggle with traction.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete paving 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime due to jealousy over men looking at his wife. The incident occurred in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and was captured on CCTV. Severiano, who had been married to Cicera for only four days, yelled at her for being a "slut" and a "whore" before the attack. After the murder, he stole a neighbor's car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found multiple weapons, including four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest, in his car. Severiano now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, revealing she came close to taking her own life. She explained that anxiety led her to believe her life was no longer worth living, citing factors such as stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson stated that while she struggled in her younger years, she has since found some peace with her condition. She emphasized the link between depression and anxiety, arguing that acknowledging this connection is essential for addressing the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson also noted that anxiety is becoming the "new depression" and highlighted the importance of seeking help through resources like beyondblue and lifeline.

A pregnant Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, was charged with second-degree assault after she beat her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 when she found the woman using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge because they deemed Curtin's actions "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin, who was seven months pregnant at the time, was set to face a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years if convicted. However, the charge was dismissed, and Curtin gave birth in January. The ex-girlfriend and the boyfriend had a history of drug use and had a child together, and they had since reconciled. Curtin's attorney argued that the ex-girlfriend had been harassing and threatening Curtin for two years, making her actions a response to prolonged abuse.

Gemma, a pit bull, was filmed in California being fed treats, but her owner tricked her by adding a broccoli spear. Gemma showed disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spat it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family. The author hopes the two children she lives with do not follow her example and learn to love vegetables.

Hsbc apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue occurred when the website for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down in 2011, was redirected to a pornographic site. The bank removed the hyperlink from its main website and denied any association with the external site, issuing an apology to the public.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton. He informed firefighters that he and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped on the second floor because it was too hot to escape through the hallway. During the 11-minute call, Marcus stayed calm, soothed his sister, and provided detailed directions to rescuers. Firefighters broke a window and rescued Marcus and his sister, who were taken to a hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The other family members, including his older brother, mother, and stepfather, escaped on their own and were also taken to a hospital.

blue fluorescent algae have illuminated australia's east coast, with amazing pictures captured in jervis bay and sydney's manly beach. the phenomenon, caused by millions of plankton emitting light, was described by photographer andy hutchinson as a `beautiful supernatural scene'. oceanography expert iain suthers explained that the algae, known as noctiluca scintillans, blooms in spring and autumn and typically occurs due to natural causes. the glow is a defense mechanism of the algae, which preys on diatoms.

A new test called Endopredict helps determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer by identifying genetic markers in the tumor, allowing patients to avoid chemotherapy if their risk of recurrence is low. After surgery, cancer cells are tested in a lab, and results can indicate a low risk of recurrence, as low as five percent. This can be as effective as chemotherapy. Most breast cancer patients receive chemotherapy to prevent recurrence, but it comes with significant side effects. Experts believe some patients may not need chemotherapy, and if the Endopredict test shows a low score, patients can choose not to undergo chemotherapy. The test is currently available privately and costs about £2,500, but there is hope it will be available on the NHS. Surgeons and specialists argue that the test allows patients to make informed decisions and could save costs by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer patient, was told her risk of recurrence was only five percent, and she chose not to have chemotherapy.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevacs over the last nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before its decommissioning. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. This follows the case of Commander Sarah West, the first female captain of a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back to the UK after allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served in the Royal Navy since 1990, with 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant, and 102 women were evacuated from Iraq due to pregnancy. Strict military rules prohibit mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and women are not required to undergo pregnancy tests before deployment.

A drone was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, carrying traces of radioactive material, including cesium, which is a byproduct of nuclear reactors. This discovery has raised concerns in Japan about the potential for terrorism involving drones. The incident occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, more than four years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular, as many Japanese view nuclear energy as too dangerous. The drone, which was 50 centimeters wide, was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing radioactive material. The government is concerned about the potential for future drone-related terrorism, especially during the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but does not restrict most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Abe was not in his office at the time, as he was in Indonesia attending the Asian-African Conference.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on the back of his motorbike. His mother suffers from Alzheimer's and he is scared she will get lost if left alone. To ensure her safety, he ties a sash around both of their waists. Lu Xincai's father passed away earlier this year, and he decided to take his mother with him to work because there was no one else to look after her. His wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai helps his mother get up at 5 am every morning, rides to work slowly to make sure she feels safe, and chats along the way. He also checks on his mother at work, who has been given her own room by his employers. Lu Xincai feels a duty to care for his mother, as she devoted her life to caring for her children. He says, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple."

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans has increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise in women's drinking habits. Heavy drinking is defined as more than one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men in a single occasion. The study also found that binge drinking rates among women increased more than seven times faster than among men. In Santa Clara County, women's binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% between 2002 and 2012. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, with 8% of Americans considered heavy drinkers and 18% binge drinkers in 2012. The increase in binge drinking is attributed to changing social norms, cultural factors, economic influences, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study also notes that about 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, and the cost of excessive drinking is estimated at over $220 billion per year.

The passage discusses concerns raised by UN officials about the increasing rate of caesarean sections in England, warning that they are putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The UN advises that caesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to infections and even death. Currently, just over a quarter of women giving birth in England have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This includes a growing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth. The UN suggests the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15%, citing the risks and costs involved. A planned caesarean costs the NHS more than a natural birth, and the WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesarean sections even without medical justification. The passage also mentions that previous research has found that as many as one in ten caesareans can cause infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, has been arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. Filkins was discovered by owner Mark Conklin on April 17, 2023, when he found her sitting in his summer home. She claimed she owned the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police later arrested her after she attempted to reenter the home. Filkins is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She is scheduled to be in court on May 14. Police have identified items missing, including furniture, decorative items, and a painting, and are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone was reunited with its owner, Bella Crooke, after police in Albury, NSW-Victoria border, used it to post selfies and humorous messages on her Facebook page to track her down. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and called her number immediately. A security guard handed the phone in, and police realized it was unlocked. They used the phone to post funny messages and photos, including one of the phone in a "holding cell," to locate Bella. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone without providing her name, as police recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella praised the police for their humorous and effective approach. She has since put a password on her phone and thanked the police for returning it.

A five-day-old baby hippo was thrown into the air and mauled to death after becoming entangled in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as it was flung into the air and dragged along the water's surface before dying hours later. The two males had been fighting for some time, and the mother stayed with her herd, believing it safer. However, one of the males grabbed the calf, leading to its death. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the event and described the tragic outcome.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is listed for £575,000, making it a bargain compared to nearby properties. However, the property comes with a three-year lease, which would cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month in rent. The property is described as bright and well-proportioned, with 1,990 sq/ft of space, including three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a utility room, along with a lift, parking, and a communal garden. It is being sold by Russell Simpson for the same price as a three-bedroom house in Stanmore, Middlesex. The property is one of two maisonettes on the market with three years left on the lease. Both require renovation. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth up to £6 million. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease for 90 years could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The properties are rare for their short leases and have attracted significant interest. However, experts warn that extending the lease could be costly and that buyers should carefully consider their options.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, was resolved by Saturday, with stores expected to return to normal operations. The incident occurred after the company had reported record quarterly earnings, with shares gaining 4.4 percent following the results. While some customers enjoyed the free drinks and shared the experience on social media, others closed their stores to avoid giving away free products. Starbucks apologized for the inconvenience and stated they were working to resolve the issue.

The passage discusses the use of rural areas in west wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, for radicalising Muslims. It mentions that individuals involved in such activities participate in seemingly ordinary community activities but have ulterior motives. The area is also noted for its use by the British military for training. Historical references include incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, with links to terrorism. Additionally, the passage highlights the role of educational institutions, such as the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, in providing knowledge that may be used for terrorist activities. Authorities stress the importance of community intelligence in detecting and preventing such activities.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, which was feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant for scientists as very little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian, Philippine, and Sea of Japan waters. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific study and potential display in museums.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in leadership, focusing on the views of Cheryl Rios, who believes that women's hormones may lead to irrational decisions, making them unsuitable for the presidency. It contrasts this with studies showing that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The text also highlights the broader issue of gender bias in leadership and the workplace, noting that even in 2015, female candidates face significant challenges. It emphasizes the importance of ending gender bias for the benefit of everyone, citing economic, familial, and social advantages of gender equality. The passage also corrects a previous error regarding Canada's first female prime minister.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor and military historian, is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques, including over 200 items, in a £100,000 sale. The auction, held at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, features notable pieces such as a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow. The auction also includes furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers, along with dozens of books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, 89, is known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill in various TV dramas, and he has also appeared in the Harry Potter films. He is set to retire from stage acting but will continue with television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their home in Winter Garden. Shemansky has been on the run since Saturday and failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day as his mother's death. The body was discovered during a well-being check by an out-of-state family member. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed the method of death. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar disorder, and was involuntarily committed for an attempted suicide. His mother was present during his divorce proceedings and may have prevented him from meeting his son, which neighbors believe contributed to his emotional state. Shemansky was last seen fleeing without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself if he arrives at her home. Anyone with information should contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene, Oregon, in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the IAAF Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed to win the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. A recent presentation convinced the IAAF that Eugene is capable of hosting the championships. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that the decision was made to take advantage of a unique opportunity, with public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic Committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public joining forces. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process. Additionally, Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 metres during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after she lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in an attempt to steal his winnings. Granger targeted Hassan after spotting him flashing a roll of £50 notes at a casino in London's West End. She used her good looks to befriend him, gaining his trust and receiving gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. On the night of the murder, Granger allowed her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and his friend Nicholas Chandler to enter Hassan's flat, where they tied him up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home to find his hidden money. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder. Her co-defendants, Jackson and Chandler, were found guilty of murder and were sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 36 years. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," highlighting the brutality of the crime. Granger expressed regret for her actions, but the judge noted her deceitfulness and loss of compassion. The trial also revealed that Hassan was oblivious to the sting, believing Granger was a genuine friend.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has experienced a decline in performance during the second half of the season. Despite a strong start, his form has dropped, and he was criticized in Spain's 2-0 defeat by the Netherlands. Fabregas, who was previously expected to break the Premier League assist record, has struggled to maintain his form, with only four assists in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. Although Chelsea are likely to win the Premier League title, questions remain about Fabregas' durability. His role in the team has declined, and his manager, Jose Mourinho, is hoping for a resurgence. Fabregas' past performance and his former club, Barcelona, have noted a trend of a late-season slump. However, with nine games remaining, Chelsea still have opportunities to rely on Fabregas' passing ability and potential form to secure the title.

West Ham is discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a trial. The 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United was invited to train with West Ham's academy and has impressed coaches after spending two weeks with the club. Beckford also has offers from clubs in Belgium and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham has revealed that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, three months after the attack. Despite evidence pointing to a suspected attacker, the police have not identified or charged anyone. The attack occurred when protesters, wearing balaclava masks and armed with iron bars on ropes, attacked Lane during a hunt. Video footage and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of suspected saboteurs, were provided to the police. Lane was beaten, kicked in the head, and suffered injuries including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The police have stated that they are shelving the investigation due to insufficient evidence, which has dismayed hunt supporters. The case highlights the difficulty police face in identifying suspects when they wear face coverings. The countryside alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid in bringing criminals to justice.

Adam Gadahn, known as "Azzam the American," was a prominent member of Al Qaeda, known for his English-language propaganda against the United States. He was born in 1978 in California, converted to Islam in 1995, and moved to Pakistan, where he joined Al Qaeda. Gadahn was involved in numerous terrorist activities, including threatening attacks on Los Angeles and Melbourne, and he criticized U.S. presidents and addressed his Jewish ancestry. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. Gadahn was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, and he was not specifically targeted. He was known as Abu Sahib in Al Qaeda and played an institutional role in the organization's media strategy. His final video, posted in 2014, called for Muslims to overthrow governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

Chinese parents are highly dedicated to raising child prodigies. A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo has gained widespread attention in China for his exceptional basketball skills, which have been showcased in a viral video. Mai has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old. The video highlights his ability to score hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously, impressing many fans. His talents have sparked numerous comments from netizens, with some questioning his father's identity and others expressing admiration for his skills. While Yao Ming is China's most renowned basketball star, Mai Zizhuo's potential has captured the public's imagination.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals,' attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, set up after the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against what it sees as the 'biased and unfair' Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. The news that O'Carroll is a backer of Hacked Off will be an embarrassment to the group, as PIE was formed in 1974 to campaign for the legalization of child sex and was linked to the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied for the age of sexual consent to be lowered to ten. O'Carroll was on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee.

bondi's icebergs club pool was drained to create a unique catwalk for mercedes-benz fashion week australia, where ten pieces presented a monochrome, unisex clothing collection designed to be worn in 20 ways. the show took place on a sunny day, with models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall, featuring a backdrop of the ocean. the event attracted crowds, including beachgoers who stopped to watch, and guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks as they viewed the androgynous designs. the presentation was part of ten pieces' capsule collection, which is produced by icebergs restaurateur maurice terzini and his partner lucy hinckfuss.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his family, including his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the trip, he posed with various animals, including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his opponent. He had previously been considered for a fight against British rival Kell Brook, but decided to proceed with Algieri.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His name was added to an Israeli memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, but his family and the organization Almagor opposed his inclusion, arguing that his death was not a terrorist act. Almagor described the incident as a rogue attack and refused to recognize Abu Khdeir as a victim of terrorism. Following complaints from his family, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed his name from the memorial wall and its website. A panel of judges had begun hearing evidence against the three suspects in his killing.

Lionel Hutz, a California-based YouTube user, filmed his young son chasing his family cat around the garden to get rest. The cat would lick the boy's fur before he sat on it, but after a short while, the cat would get up and move to another spot. The boy would then follow the cat to the new location and repeat the process. The cat eventually stopped being used as a pillow and went indoors. Later, the boy and cat were seen making up and the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with one trial witness, Robert Kushner, having lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying against police wrongdoing. He testified that some of the undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner had passed a background check when he was hired in 2010 and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. He also coaches in a Narberth summer league, where he is described as an excellent coach. Lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering claim the government's case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

A chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, exploded and caught fire, injuring six people. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical. The explosion occurred after an oil leak at an oil storage facility. Five of the six injured were treated for injuries from broken glass. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. The plant had previously exploded in July 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has led to protests, some of which have been violent. The plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated due to pollution concerns in 2007.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, has a message for Premier League referees, stating that he will not change his habit of wearing his socks low on his shinpads, a practice he has maintained due to superstition. Despite making his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, Grealish expressed that the game was tough, especially in a relegation battle, but he was pleased with the opportunity. He emphasized his commitment to his superstition and his desire to earn more starts during the season.

bobbi kristina brown, the daughter of bobby brown and whitney houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother, cissy houston. Despite being out of a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. A source confirmed she is in the same neurological state for nearly three months, not responding to visitors or familiar voices, and has a tracheostomy. Two days after her father, bobby brown, claimed her condition had improved, stating she was awake and watching him, an attorney noted that while her condition has improved, the quality of her life remains uncertain. She is currently undergoing a long rehabilitation process.

Russia is on the brink of reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany's Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova won 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova also won her match against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova mentioned that Lisicki's powerful play was challenging. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia now needs one more win in their remaining matches on Sunday to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the one that caused three days of severe weather last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hinder cleanup efforts, with over 4,409 of 24,196 jobs still pending. The SES is particularly worried about the impact on the Hunter region, which was heavily affected by the previous storm. Weather forecasts suggest that the new weather system will be slightly further from the coast and may not affect Sydney as heavily as last week's storm. The Bureau of Meteorology notes that heavy rainfall is likely in coastal areas of the northeastern part of the state and southeastern Queensland. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's song "La Vida Loco," denied claims that she attempted suicide after collapsing due to low blood pressure. She posted photos of her injuries on Instagram and clarified that she was treated in the hospital and was recovering at home. Italian media initially reported that she had tried to take her own life, but she denied these claims, stating that the reports were inaccurate. She also mentioned that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, had been in Naples at the time of the incident. Additionally, Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzi photographer who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities. She and Corona have a son together, Carlos Maria.

The passage discusses a poll indicating that the British public hopes Kate and William will name their second child after William's mother, Diana, the Princess of Wales. Diana is the most preferred name for a girl, followed by Alice and Charlotte. For a boy, James is the most favored name. The poll also shows that a quarter of respondents hope for a female baby, while only three percent expect a younger brother. Additionally, the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated his explosives near protesters in Khost, Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding dozens. An Afghan lawmaker was among the wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed the attack. The attackers were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

dani alves is set to leave barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four spanish titles and the champions league twice. Alves has been unable to agree on a new deal and will leave the nou camp this summer. His agent, dinorah santana, confirmed that he rejected a three-year contract extension, which was dependent on him playing in 60% of matches. She stated that the negotiations are over, as barcelona had not considered renewing his contract by april.

pablo osvaldo has suggested that andrea pirlo and francesco totti should move to boca juniors in argentina. osvaldo, who joined boca on a loan from southampton, has already become a fan favorite, scoring three goals in six games. he believes pirlo and totti would fit well at boca due to their south-american style and popularity, and he thinks the fans would love to have them at la bombonera. pirlo is a top midfielder and a world-class player, while totti is a roma legend and would be highly popular in argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, fell from his horse in a spectacular double somersault during a race at Wincanton, leaving him with a minor injury. The incident, which went viral online, has made him an internet sensation. Despite the dramatic fall, Ferguson remained undeterred and returned to riding. He described the fall as the most impressive he had seen and expressed gratitude for being unharmed. Although he received some abuse and gained a significant number of Twitter followers, he views it as harmless banter. Ferguson also humorously considered the possibility of pursuing a gymnastics career after finishing racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showed off his inner Iron Man in a serious-looking Instagram post after the release of the "Avengers: Age of Ultron" movie. The movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre, featuring A-list cast members like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who returned to London Wasps for the 2012 season after playing in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has surpassed the 100 appearance mark for the club and is a key player in the England squad with 57 caps to date.

The passage discusses the rise of wide leg trousers as a key trend for SS15. These trousers, available in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, and striped, offer an effortless and fresh alternative to skinny jeans. Louise Redknapp and Emma note that wide leg trousers can provide a welcome change from skinny jeans, which have been popular for many years. The trend has seen a resurgence since the 1970s, with Louise previously trying the look seven years ago. While wide leg trousers can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals, the key to wearing them successfully is pairing them with high heels and simple top halves to elongate the legs. Denim is highlighted as the easiest way to achieve the trend, with Gucci and Topshop offering various styles. The passage also suggests that wide leg trousers are versatile and can be worn in different settings, from casual to evening wear, and recommends shopping for them at stores like Topshop and Finery London. Poppy Delevingne was seen wearing the trend at the AW15 Chloe show in Paris.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition against the showing, citing concerns about the film's portrayal of the Iraq War and its impact on the Middle East. However, a backlash followed, leading to a counter-petition asking for reconsideration. In a statement, University of Michigan's Vice President for Student Life, E. Royster Harper, apologized for the initial decision to cancel the showing, stating it was inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression. The film will be shown as part of the Umix social events, with an alternative screening of the family-friendly movie "Paddington" available for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper." The decision received praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

A quokka was the victim of a cruel act by two French tourists who tried to set the Australian animal alight on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The two men, aged 18 and 24, allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to contact the quokka, which was singed but survived. Detectives questioned the men and seized video evidence of the incident. Both men were evicted from the island and have been charged with animal cruelty, with court appearances scheduled for April 17. Quokkas, which are the size of a domestic cat, can be found on some small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, never saw any of the films made of her. Her photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years, so she had never seen herself dancing. With help from filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers, a video of "soundies" was created and shown to Barker at her nursing home, which she found delightful.

The passage discusses a decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain. New figures show that a third of men have never washed their own car, with three-quarters of women never doing so. The study, conducted by a vehicle leasing firm, found that only 12% of men who wash their cars do it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include the availability of car washes, more shops open on Sundays, and the rise of live football on TV. Additionally, the increasing size of vehicles and a lack of interest from children in earning money by washing cars are also factors. However, during holidays like Easter, more people wash their cars. The frequency of car washing varies by city and vehicle type, with certain cities and car brands being more likely to have their cars washed by owners.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's positive impact on him since Gerrard joined Anfield in 2008. Gerrard is set to play for Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead his hometown team to the final on his birthday, May 30. If Liverpool win, Gerrard will end his Anfield career in the final before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. Despite Liverpool being a different side without Gerrard, Skrtel believes the club has potential replacements. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool lineup for the Villa match after serving three-match bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, achieved a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, marking his first such feat on the hallowed turf. He played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, and his achievement was notable as it was the first of five hole-in-ones on the day, leveling the record from 2002. Although Nicklaus did not win the contest, he became the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963 and collected his sixth in 1986. He is one of five men to complete the career grand slam, an accolade that Rory McIlroy could achieve if he wins his third major in succession.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens blared in Kansas as several storms reported tornadoes, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard. The storm moved northeast, missing the city but posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned about the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional reports of tornadoes were received in southwestern Kansas, with three sightings near Aetna. Kansas was not the only state affected, as a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri. Reports of wind damage and flooding were also received in leadington, with aerial footage showing damage to roofs and streets. In Farmington, a Twitter user reported baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

A Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, accused of fatally shooting a man he claims he meant to subdue with a taser, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter. During a hearing, the judge allowed Bates to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which prompted a response from the family of the victim, Eric Harris. They expressed concern over Bates' decision, stating it sends a message of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates was working as a reserve deputy when he was involved in the arrest of Harris during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates claims the shooting was accidental. He has apologized to the Harris family, as has Sheriff Stanley Glanz. The family's lawyer claims Bates was not qualified for the force and received preferential treatment. The Tulsa World newspaper reported that some supervisors were told to forge Bates' records and were reassigned when they refused. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied these allegations. Over the weekend, one of Bates' lawyers released most of his training documents, stating they prove Bates had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11. He has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, accompanied by the phrase "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor claims Aldo lacks the same motivation as him and has a fractious relationship with Aldo. McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin, indicating his desire to hold the title. Aldo is making his eighth defense of the belt against McGregor in Las Vegas.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after he skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, which they argued glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, criticized Abbott for promoting a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing. Despite this, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, suggesting that demonstrating healthy habits through activities like exercise could be more beneficial. Abbott's incident is not the first by a Prime Minister, but critics argue that attitudes towards binge drinking have shifted, and Abbott should have considered the current concerns.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases linked to Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 the previous week. The increase is attributed to a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants. The outbreak is primarily among intravenous drug users and involves the use of the painkiller Opana. Health officials are considering extending the 30-day program, but Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. The future of the program and legislation allowing needle exchanges in other counties is uncertain, with concerns about funding and long-term sustainability. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that high rates of hepatitis C are a key indicator of needle-sharing and potential HIV outbreaks.

The passage describes a football fan's girlfriend, Saskia, who took a test on Arsenal FC created by her boyfriend. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and an 'in your own words' section. Saskia scored 87% and received an 'A' grade, but her boyfriend noted she could have done better on some questions. The test included questions about Arsenal's history, players, and team positions. Some questions were answered correctly by Saskia, while others were not. The boyfriend was impressed with her performance and did not dump her. The story highlights the boyfriend's obsession with Arsenal and the public's reaction to the test, with some calling him a 'legend' and others suggesting it was a bit of a farce. The passage also includes some specific questions and answers from the test, such as the nickname for Arsenal fans (the "Gunners"), the current manager of Arsenal (Unai Emery), and the answer to the question about the 'FC' in Arsenal FC, which stands for "Footbal Club."

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel who worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years, is facing deportation from the United States after retiring due to declining health. Toro, 66, was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his cooperation but has not received it. The DEA refused to assist him with his citizenship after he came public with his plight. Toro, who helped carry out undercover operations worldwide and contributed to the prosecution of drug lords like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, now lives in the U.S. illegally and is in a legal limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or obtain a green card or passport. He is preparing to go into hiding if deported, stating he has atoned for his past mistakes and is only seeking the citizenship he was promised.

A 14-year-old girl from India was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village in Mathura district. After the attack, her family told her to remain quiet. The girl set herself on fire with kerosene on Tuesday, leading to her being treated in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. The incident has heightened awareness of sexual assault in India, following the release of a documentary about the 2012 gang rape and murder of a Delhi student, Jyoti Singh. This event led to widespread protests and calls for more protection for women. The attention on the issue has also led to changes in legal procedures, with the lawyer's association refusing to defend the perpetrators.

Louis van Gaal, the manager of Manchester United, expressed his desire to win the upcoming derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford. However, key players Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw have been ruled out due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal emphasized that being fit for a match is different from just being physically able to play. He also mentioned that if United win, they could finish as high as third and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal acknowledged that Manchester City will be a strong challenge but stressed the importance of controlling aggression and not seeking revenge for a previous loss. He also looked forward to the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices during a Premier League match at Emirates Stadium. They left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of the game to raise awareness about the high costs of attending matches, with tickets starting at £64 for the 12.45pm kick-off. The protest came after the Premier League announced a £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans displayed banners criticizing the price discrepancy, with one reading '£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket'. Both clubs' fans gathered outside the stadium to show their discontent, and organizers called ticket prices 'extortionate'. The protest highlighted the growing frustration among fans facing high costs, with calls for tangible price reductions. Further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, her parents, Jade and Matthew Reader, were told she needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match, so her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, a twin sister, donated part of her liver to save Star. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery. She now requires regular blood tests and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life. Shanell's decision to donate her liver was made without hesitation, as she considered Star her niece and was willing to help her.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake, along with their teammates Loic Remy and Willian, participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, Hazard and Ake secured a 5-3 win by firing balls into the boot of a car from close range. In the second round, they faced a challenge involving sinking balls into a convertible Audi from long range, with Hazard and Ake winning again, taking a 6-0 lead. In the final challenge, the players shot from long range aiming to sink their footballs through the top of a convertible Audi. Willian and Remy redeemed themselves to produce a shock win over their team-mates, but Willian caused a mishap by smashing the wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range effort. Remy reacted by putting his hands on his head, and Willian was allowed to drive one of the Audis that was part of the challenge.

A former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, 54, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal on the day of the crash. His wife, Deborah Dellinger, described him as a man of ethics and integrity, despite his health issues. The crash occurred when Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph, causing the victims' SUV to be sheared apart. Dellinger's attorneys argued he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis. The couple had met while working at a home for the elderly. Dellinger was initially charged with reckless manslaughter but the charges were upgraded to negligent homicide. He was arraigned in December 2013 and was also involved in a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt at a suburban New York hospital. She was sentenced to 20 years to life, sparing her the maximum 25 years to life. Spears showed no emotion during her sentencing. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, demanding she be punished severely and noted her lack of emotion. The judge mentioned Spears suffers from a mental illness and described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued Spears acted out of a need for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was a loving mother and intended to appeal the verdict. Spears' social media posts, including photos of her son's final hours, were used as evidence. The prosecution blamed Spears for her son's short and tormented life, citing her use of his medical issues to gain attention.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains: influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket. This update was prompted by a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States, where the previous vaccine did not adequately cover these strains. The vaccine stocks arrived a month later than expected. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting in April 20. Experts recommend getting the vaccine, as it provides protection against H3N2, B/Phuket, and H1N1. Dr. Alan Hampson emphasizes the importance of vaccination, even for those not in high-risk groups, to help protect others.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site against an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could threaten its management. The state of Illinois, which calls itself the "Land of Lincoln," is facing a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site. The tomb, which is a popular tourist attraction, was criticized in the latest National Geographic issue for lacking historical character. Despite this, the tomb has undergone significant renovations and is in excellent physical condition. The tomb's design was originally by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and was dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874. The site is currently facing challenges due to reduced hours, fewer staff, and potential future budget cuts.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and 2000s fashion trends, highlighting several styles that have made a comeback. These include chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts. It also covers specific fashion items such as the bucket hat, camouflage print, double denim, UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets, and harem trousers. The text provides examples of how these trends have evolved over time, with modern celebrities and fashion icons reviving them in contemporary settings.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

The passage highlights various trending stories from a busy week. It mentions four rainbows appearing in the New York area, Amanda Curtis capturing a lucky photo, the ban on exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, RDJ's agitation during an interview, a new trend of lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner, a 102-year-old woman time-traveling with filmmakers, a prom-posal involving bombs leading to accusations of racism, Ewan McGregor joining the cast of "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable role in "Black Mass," and a humorous way to announce pregnancy by referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
